name: Billionaires
bio: Microsoft founder no doubt sleeping easier after settling pesky federal antitrust suit. This year the world’s richest man will even get a little extra pocket change – about $100 million – from company’s first shareholder dividend. Microsoft no longer the torrid growth machine it once was, but is weathering tech storm better than most. Having kicked himself upstairs to more cerebral job of chief software architect, Gates is busy working with developers to push Microsoft beyond the desktop into devices like tablet PCs, cell phones, TVs.  Maintaining secrecy on next version of Windows (dubbed Longhorn, set for release in 2005), claims it&#39s not just an upgrade. Meanwhile tackling global health and education with $24 billion Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. Funds flowing to disease prevention (polio, AIDS), vaccine development; lately buying drug stocks. Diversifies own wealth via Cascade Investments: Corbis, stakes in Republic Services, Canadian National Railway, Gabelli Asset Management.

name: Billionaires
bio: Omaha oracle’s Berkshire Hathaway back on track and profitable again after posting substantial losses on reinsurance business last year in wake of World Trade Center attacks. This year, Buffet’s buying into bankrupt mobile home maker Oakwood Homes.  But value investor also dipped into telecom: Last year bought $100 million in high-yield paper from Level 3. Also picking through scraps of fallen energy giants: $900 million plus debt to Dynegy for gas pipelines, helped pump $2 billion into troubled Williams Co., said to be looking for bargains among Enron&#39s assets. Heart of portfolio leans toward blue chips: Gillette, Coca-Cola. Says he&#39s "disgusted" by corporate bosses who tout their companies while selling shares: "These business leaders view shareholders as patsies, not partners." Buffett has never sold a share of Berkshire Hathaway.

name: Billionaires
bio: Microsoft cofounder finding it harder to cling to "wired world" vision: Struggling under $20 billion in debt, accounting probes and a plummeting stock price, his Charter Communications cable company is likely facing bankruptcy or restructuring. Luckily, didn't completely turn his back on Microsoft: still thought to hold 213 million shares. Claims to have liquidated 75% of the diverse equity holdings in private investment firm Vulcan Ventures, reinvesting much in Treasury paper. Sports enthusiast owns football's Seattle Seahawks, basketball's Portland Trailblazers.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Syracuse University-educated Saudi prince is still the wealthiest single investor outside the U.S., despite a drop in value of many of his American-based holdings. Clearly a thrill-seeker, Alwaleed says this past year he sank another $1 billion into Citigroup stock (down 22% since last year). Says his stock losses were offset by the rise in value of real estate in Riyadh and Kingdom Center, a tony shopping center he opened there in late 2001.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brash founder of database maker Oracle focusing on government as dot-com clients evaporate. Salespeople may have tried too hard to please their demanding boss: $95 million deal with California nixed after audit found that Oracle sold state more software than it needed. Now promoting national security database (donated by Oracle) as answer to terrorism. With Oracle sales down 12% this past year EllisonOs fortune is suffering, too: down from $23 billion last year, $58 billion in 2000. That still leaves enough to float an America's Cup entry in February (see story, p. 296). Took Oracle public one day before Microsoft in 1986; remains second-largest software maker behind Gates' shop. Rivalry with Bill goes on: now making Oracle machines compatible with Windows alternative Linux, calling for open-source competitor to ubiquitous MS Office suite.

name: Billionaires
bio: Child of Sam Walton (d. 1992), founder of world's largest retailer Wal-Mart. Started with general store in Arkansas in 1962. Now 4,300 stores worldwide, serving 100 million customers a week. Wal-Mart considering bid for British supermarket chain Safeway. Family no longer in day-to-day control but still owns 38 percent of stock. Rob is chairman of board, also vintage auto enthusiast. Vietnam vet John is major backer of education causes, school choice, founded Children's Scholarship Fund with Ted Forstmann. Jim heads family's banking activities, heads Arvest, Arkansas' largest bank. Horse enthusiast Alice lives on Texas ranch. Family foundation recently donated $300 million to U. of Arkansas, largest-ever gift to U.S. public university. Money will go to graduate education and honors college for undergrads.

name: Billionaires
bio: France’s richest person is a billion dollars richer this year, thanks mostly to the impressive resilience of her principle holding, L’Oréal. The company continues to thrive under its English chief executive, Lindsay Owen-Jones, who boosted profits 1.8% to 713 million euros in the first half of 2002. Bettencourt inherited a controlling stake in L’Oréal in 1957 from her father, the company’s founder. As discreet as she is rich, Bettencourt shuns the press. Part of the reason may be an impressive number of skeletons in the family closet, most relating to the family’s intimate association with extreme-right political groups in Vichy France. Only daughter and heir apparent Françoise Bettencourt Meyers sits on L’Oréal’s board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite a bout with prostate cancer last year, the 76-year-old founder of home furnishings giant IKEA has no intention of retiring.  Entrepreneurial from the start, Kamprad sold matches, fish, pens and Christmas cards by bicycle as a teenager. Outside of work, he travels coach, carries his own bags and is often seen doing his own shopping at the local supermarket. And he continues to cycle.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her three children, inherited an estimated  $4.5 billion fortune from now-deceased husband Gad Rausing, who ran packaging giant Tetra Laval for 5 years, after buying out his brother Hans in 1995.   Daughter Kirsten and brothers Finn and Jörn are nonexecutive members of group’s board. In mid-January, the heirs scored a major victory in their battle against the European antitrust commission when it finally approved Tetra Laval’s takeover of French food packaging company Sidel SA.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ebullient chief executive of Microsoft has been shedding pounds (more than 50 this year) while increasing workload. Protege Richard Belluzzo stepped down after 14 months as Microsoft president, left Ballmer with nearly double the number of execs under his command. Found other ways to delegate: MicrosoftOs 7 main divisions (MSN, Business Solutions, Server and Tools, etc.) now handle own budgets. In June announced kinder, gentler company mission: "To enable people and businesses throughout the world to realize their full potential." One business grappling with Microsoft's potential: AOL. Following expensive promotional campaign, Web portal MSN.com claims it has converted 450,000 AOL customers. Detroit native Ballmer dropped out of Stanford M.B.A. program to join Harvard classmate Bill Gates 1980. Running Microsoft day-to-day since 1998.

name: Billionaires
bio: She and sister, Barbara Cox Anthony, inherited newspaper fortune started by James M. Cox (d. 1957). Sisters own 98% of $8.7 billion (sales) media empire: 17 daily newspapers (flagship: Atlanta Journal-Constitution), 30 nondaily papers, 15 TV stations, 81 radio stations. Also used cars via Manheim Auto Auctions, more than $54 billion worth sold last year. Anne, a Democratic fundraiser, avid gardener and ambassador to Belgium under President Carter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Spain's richest man and one of the richest self-made entrepreneurs in Europe, he started $3.4 billion (sales) textile chain Inditex in 1985. Also the most casual: refuses to wear a tie. Amazing ability to ride out global recession: company's net income grew 31% in 2001 and was projected to grow 20% last year. Already in 43 countries, recently opened the first outlet of its flagship Zara store in Sweden, the backyard of its biggest rival, Hennes & Mauritz (headed by fellow billionaire Stefan Perrson). Ortega has made personal investments in such diverse industries as electric and gas, banking and tourism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner, with siblings John and Jacqueline, of Mars Inc., nation’s largest candymaker: M&Ms, Milky Way, Snickers, 3 Musketeers. Also pet food (Sheba, Whiskas, Pedigree), Uncle Ben’s Rice. Forrest Sr. (d. 1999) ran supersecretive confectionery with iron fist. Estimated sales: $15 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner, with siblings John and Forrest Jr., of Mars Inc., nation’s largest candymaker: M&Ms, Milky Way, Snickers, 3 Musketeers. Also pet food (Sheba, Whiskas, Pedigree), Uncle Ben’s Rice. Forrest Sr. (d. 1999) ran supersecretive confectionery with iron fist. Estimated sales: $15 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner, with siblings Forrest Jr. and Jacqueline, of Mars Inc., nation’s largest candymaker: M&Ms, Milky Way, Snickers, 3 Musketeers. Also pet food (Sheba, Whiskas, Pedigree), Uncle Ben’s Rice. Forrest Sr. (d. 1999) ran supersecretive confectionery with iron fist. Estimated sales: $15 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Winner of PC wars pursuing new markets in higher-end machines and services, printers and handheld devices. Despite gains, big jump in profits, stock price remains sluggish. Longtime seller tried to give it a boost by buying back 8 million shares in late 2001, predicting imminent surge in consumer spending. Started Dell Computer in dorm room at U. of Texas in 1984: became known for wily direct-selling tactics, keeping costs low to win price wars against Gateway, Compaq.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abigail and her father Edward Johnson run Fidelity Investments, nation’s largest mutual fund company, with $770 billion under management, but lately feeling effects of slumping stock market: $100 billion sapped from accounts. With flagship Magellan Fund down 21%, company now playing it more conservatively, pushing new Treasury bond fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Who&#39s the boss?" is question of the year at Viacom after publicized bickering between the Viacom chief and President Mel Karmazin. Apparently patched up, but still unknown whether Karmazin will land new contract next year. Daughter Shari an unlikely replacement, but taking more active role in company affairs. Father started drive-in movie business 1954. Media empire now includes CBS, Paramount, MTV, Infinity Broadcasting. Newly engaged, controls two-thirds of Viacom voting stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Knicknamed Superman, Asia’s richest and most influential billionaire. Centered on the conglomerate Hutchinson Whampoa (telecom, port services, real estate),  Li’s empire spans 41 countries and accounts for 13% of Hong Kong’s stock market value.   Has invested more than $7 billion in mainland China and built 400 miles of roads and bridges. He has given away over $500 million to support education and health care facilities in Asia. Now betting heavily on 3G.

name: Billionaires
bio: Slowdown in ad spending putting a damper on Newhouse media empire, but Donald and his brother, Samuel Newhouse Jr., still eager to take back management of its 2.3 million cable subscribers from partnership with AOL Time Warner. Brothers inherited company from father Sam Sr. (d. 1979). Donald runs newspaper division (Newark Star-Ledger, Cleveland Plain Dealer); This year shuttered 66-year-old Mademoiselle, bought Modern Bride. Owns 41 city business journals, Golf Digest and fashion industry bible Women’s Wear Daily.

name: Billionaires
bio: Slowdown in ad spending putting a damper on Newhouse media empire, but Samuel and his brother, Donald Newhouse, still eager to take back management of its 2.3 million cable subscribers from partnership with AOL Time Warner. Inherited company from father Sam Sr. (d. 1979). Samuel oversees Condé Nast, publisher of glamour glossies Vogue, Vanity Fair, the New Yorker. This year shuttered 66-year-old Mademoiselle, bought Modern Bride. Owns 41 city business journals, Golf Digest and fashion industry bible Women’s Wear Daily.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold his 50% stake in family’s packaging company Tetra Laval to his brother, Gad, in 1995 for a reported $7 billion. He has now gone into direct competion with his deceased brother’s empire by investing in Ecolean, a new packaging company that produces highly biodegradable products. But Tetra Laval can relax for now: tiny Ecolean has sales of just $10 million (2001) and has yet to make a profit. When not vacationing at his mansion in Barbados, Rausing collects vintage cars and raises deer on his 900-acre East Sussex estate, which he shares with wife, Marit, and dog, Tess.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Robert (see), who along with brother, Jay (d. 1999), inherited fortune started by grandfather in 1902. Today Thomas runs far-flung Pritzker Organization: hotels (Hyatt chain), Royal Caribbean Cruises, mining equipment, railroad cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: The richest man in England is quite a bit richer with property prices in the U.K having yet another stellar year. Still, life wasn't all roses for the Duke of Westminster last year, who endured an embarrassing lawsuit from a former housekeeper who alleged she was unfairly dismissed. The press feasted on juicy allegations such as: The housekeeper could return from walking the family dog at 5:30 each morning only if the dog had "done two poos and a wee." The Duchess also allegedly insisted that the toilet paper rolls in each of the 20 bathrooms be positioned so that precisely two sheets hung down. (The housekeeper lost the suit.)

name: Billionaires
bio: Latin America’s richest man is $3 billion poorer this year. That’s mostly because his mammoth holdings in Mexico&#39s telecom and financial sectors suffered double-digit percentage losses on the Mexican bourse last year at the same time that the Mexican peso fell against the dollar. Still he remains a headliner, most recently for bankrolling the multimillion-dollar tab to bring former New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani to clean up Mexico City’s epidemic crime rates. On the business front his Teléfonos de México remains the object of criticism for allegedly monopolistic behavior that preserves high phone prices and poor phone service south of the border.

name: Billionaires
bio: Money manager known for big bets: made $1 billion on British pound 1992, lost $2 billion during Russian crisis 1998. Despite the ups and downs Quantum fund mostly up: average returns of 31% over its 30-year history. Recently hired Julian Robertson protégé Robert Bishop to guide $11.5 billion investment and real estate portfolio, most owned by Soros family.

name: Billionaires
bio: The luxury-goods king, Arnault created and still manages the sprawling LVMH luxury-goods empire that includes everything from Louis Vuitton bags to Moët champagne to TAG Heuer watches. LVMH remains the locus of the vast bulk of Arnault’s wealth, with virtually all of it tied up in a near-40% stake in the company. Arnault, a father of five, did end up with some egg on his face last year though, when he threw in the towel in his failed attempt to turn English auction house Phillips de Pury & Luxembourg into a viable competitor to Christie’s and Sotheby’s. After plowing more than $100 million into the auction house, he sold LVMH’s majority stake in it last year for an undisclosed price.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over from his father as head of retailing sensation Hennes & Mauritz in 1998. Has ably steered H&M since: last year, net profits increased 50%; 110 new stores are slated to open in 2003. Revamping less than stellar U.S. business by cutting back on the unpopular men’s line, focusing on more-fashion-conscious women and hiring celebrities like photographer Richard Avedon for fashion shoots. On a sad personal note, his father, Erling, who founded H&M in 1947, died last October at the age of 85.

name: Billionaires
bio: Three brothers inherited a real estate empire in 1990 following their father’s death. Their Sun Hung Kai is one of the largest real estate developers in Hong Kong, selling $1.9 billion worth of residential real estate a year; also includes Hong Kong’s wireless phone service provider SmarTone and bus operator Kowloon Motor Bus. The brothers have been making major forays into mainland China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Busy year for the chairman and president of George Weston Ltd., one of North America&#39s largest bakers. Aside from tending to his controlling stake in Loblaw&#39s, also minds upscale retailers Holt Renfrew and Brown Thomas. Family also runs Associated British Foods. Last year the family took Fortnum & Mason—Queen Elizabeth&#39s grocer—private. Wife Hilary, Ontario&#39s former Lieutenant Governor (her term terminated March 2002), donated her salary to support youth-related programs. An avid collector of avant-garde artist Christo, Weston funded a recent exhibit at Windsor, his private community in Vero Beach, Florida.

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout took job selling stuffed toys. Quit, started own line of stuffed cats, other animals. Hit pay dirt with Beanie Babies: understuffed animals affordably priced for those on an allowance. Kids love the cute names (Hissy the snake), adults fall for commemorative releases (Courage the dog, in honor of 9/11 rescuers). Now sponsors World Cup and launching operations in New Zealand, Australia, Korea. Also hotels, including Four Seasons in New York, Santa Barbara.

name: Billionaires
bio: The wealthiest man in Italy has been Italy’s prime  minister since 2001. Has the support of the Italian parliament who approved a law he pushed allowing trials to move to new venues if there is doubt about judge’s objectivity, despite heated objections. His invesment holding company Fininvest owns almost half of Mediaset, one of Italy’s largest television network. Also holds banking, insurance and publishing interests. In his off-hours, minds his soccer team, A.C. Milan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of satellite-TV provider EchoStar in pending deal to buy Hughes Electronic's DirecTV, but antitrust concerns may scrap deal. Ten state attorneys general already probing firm over accusations of anticonsumer business practices. Former Frito-Lay financial analyst launched satellite network 1980 to broadcast TV to rural areas. Today 7.5 million subscribers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Bangalore-based Wipro, India’s largest (market cap) technology company, of which he owns 84%. Premji beefed up the business with acquisitions, paying $26 million for the energy practice of Nasdaq-listed IT consultancy, American Management Systems. He shelled out another $102 million for Spectramind, an Indian call-center firm. Drives a six-year-old Ford. Recently Premji learned to play golf.

name: Billionaires
bio: A corporate raider in 1980s with big scores in Texaco, USX and TWA, now prefers the label "shareholder activist." Made $800 million selling Nabisco, shorting Priceline. Recently tussled with Ted Forstmann (see) over control of ailing XO Communications, and bought nearly $1 billion in bonds of bankrupt Federal-Mogul.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abramovich lost his parents as a child, dropped out of college and then made a small fortune in a series of oil export deals in the early 1990s. His fortunes took off in 1995, when he teamed up with Russia’s most powerful crony capitalist, Boris Berezovsky, to take over oil giant Sibneft at a fraction of its market value. When Berezovsky fled Russia in 2000 to escape fraud charges; Abramovich bought out his stakes in Sibneft and the ORT television network. Also bought half of Russia’s largest aluminum company. Today he’s governor of the impoverished arctic region of Chukhotka, but retains investments through his British-registered holding company, Millhouse Capital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandson of BASF founder, he orchestrated the sale of pharmaceutical firms Boehringer Mannheim and DePuy Inc. to Roche in 1997 for $11 billion. Deal netted him $4.4 billion in cash. Retired, he now lives in Bermuda with his fourth wife, Heidemarie. Thanks to an endowment by Engelhorn, Pulitzer Prize-winning author Katherine Anne Porter’s home in Kyle, Tex., was renovated and is maintained as a writers’ center by Southwest Texas State University. Engelhorn’s American mother, Anita Schlimmer, was a childhood friend of Porter’s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Workaholic founder of Luxottica, the world’s largest designer and manufacturer of high-quality eyeglass frames, with annual sales of more than $3 billion in 2001. His U.S. brands—Ray-Ban, optical chain LensCrafters, Sunglass Hut—are ubiquitous. Even the lesser-known labels enjoy success. The Persol brand designed glasses for the  James Bond flick, Die Another Day. Sent to an orphanage at the age of 7 because his mother could not afford to support her five children. Apprentice at a factory that made molds for auto parts, eyeglass frames; opened his own molding shop in 1958 at the age of 23.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of banker Wilhelm von Finck, who founded insurance giant Allianz and private bank Merck, Finck & Co. After selling the bank to Barclays in 1990, he moved his money to tax-paradise Switzerland, where he lives with wife Francine. He still owns stakes in insurance, mining and chemical companies, a retail chain, property rental and leasing, a producer of champagne, as well as a sizable portion of Swiss restaurant-and-hotel chain Moevenpick.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started out with one newspaper in Adelaide, Australia. Now entrenched in television (35 stations, Fox Network), movies (20th Century Fox), newspapers (New York Post, U.K.Os Sun), satellites (Star TV), book publishing (HarperCollins). Also cable: Fox News Channel (including business show Forbes on Fox). Known for taking big gambles, now grappling to gain control of troubled Gemstar-TV Guide and negotiating for VivendiOs Italian pay TV unit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs the $24 billion (sales) Otto GmbH & Co., the world’s largest mail-order company. Internet sales rose 56% to $1.8 billion in 2001, ranking the group as the second-largest Internet retailer, behind only Amazon.com. With his 93-year-old father, who founded the company in 1949, and four siblings, owns 65% of Otto Versand, more than 50% of home furnishings chain Crate & Barrel, ailing catalog retailer Spiegel and $2 billion in real estate. Michael is a passionate environmentalist who promotes environmentally friendly products in his catalog and supports several foundations for the preservation of clean water.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Herbert Quandt, who rescued BMW from bankruptcy, and his third wife, Johanna. Inherited a 12.5% share of luxury car maker BMW and a 50.1% ownership of pharmaceutical manufacturer Altana. Holder of a business degree, sits on Altana’s advisory board and has helped transform the $2.45 billion sales company into a world-class corporation that joined the German DAX list of 30 top companies last September. Married with three children, Susanne shares her family’s penchant for privacy and keeps a very low profile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $3.1 billion (revenues) Mohammed Abdulmohsin Al-Kharafi & Sons, a contracting group. While elder brother Jassim is chairman, President Nasser is believed to be in charge. (Sister Faiza is president of Kuwait University.) The brothers are trying to woo European tourists to their Disney-esque Port Galib on Egypt’s Red Sea coast, a project estimated at $2 billion. The fledgling resort’s French-managed airport began accepting commercial flights in late 2001. The brothers travel often to London, while the younger Al-Kharafis prefer U.S. hot spots like Los Angeles, Miami and New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: Image of Ebay founder mildly tarnished after revelation involving famed Pez anecdote: turns out the French &eacute;migr&eacute; didn't create the online auctioneer so his girlfriend could trade the candy dispensers. At least the white lie hasn't hurt his company, one of the few Internet success stories. All but 1% of his wealth pledged to philanthropy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oil and gas greased the tracks to railroad riches; rail led to a fortune in fiber optics. But with fiber out of favor and Qwest's accounting under suspicion, his 18% stake is down $6.5 billion. New focus: movie houses. Spent an estimated $825 million cobbling together a string of troubled theaters. Took Regal Entertainment public 2002; stake in 5,800-screen exhibitor now worth $1.3 billion. Secretive tycoon avoids media but loves entertainment: owns pro hockey's LA Kings, one-third of basketballOs LA Lakers, half of Major League Soccer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bloomberg's core business of selling business information may be up, but his other fiefdom, New York City, not doing as well. Mayor Mike charmed city with subway commute and $1 salary. Budget shortfalls from Wall Street slump and Sept. 11 aftermath may force bus and subway fare increases that could damage his appeal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Young, handsome and glamorous, he inherited Swiss biotech concern Serono from father in 1996. As chief executive, he has transformed the drug firm into a biotech giant that has leading treatments for infertility and multiple sclerosis. Bertarelli has an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School and a bachelor’s of science from Boston-based Babson College. Well known for his yachting passion: His Team Alinghi, made up of close to 100 sailors, boatbuilders and scientists, is a contender to win this year’s America’s Cup.  He is married and has one child.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the founders and current Chairman of Benetton Group, one of the largest fashion retailers in the world. Group also has stakes in Autostrade, Italy’s largest operator and builder of toll motorways; and Autogrill, a chain of off-highway eateries. Luciano’s luxurious office, decked out in 17th-century frescoes, is dubbed Sala dei Giganti (Room of the Giants), thanks to the fresco of four chiseled men whose figures run up the walls and across the curved ceiling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Probably the most tightly held of the big French companies, Chanel remains 100% in the hands of Alain and Gerard Wertheimer, the grandsons of the company’s founder, Pierre Wertheimer. Extremely secretive, the brothers are said to reside in both Switzerland and France. Alain’s the one who runs Chanel, which analysts say is growing its revenues even during the downturn. Both brothers are enthusiastic equestrians.

name: Billionaires
bio: After growing up in the Ukrainian city of Lvov, Fridman came to Moscow to study at the Institute of Steel and Alloys in the 1980s. Founded Alfa Group in 1988 with a group of college friends; now diverse conglomerate with oil, retail, telecom, Russia’s largest private bank.  Recently announced plans to merge his oil company, TNK, with the Russian oil interests of BP, for $6.75 billion--quite an achievement, considering that four years ago BP was in a bitter fight against what it claimed were Fridman’s unorthodox methods in taking over a partly BP-owned oil field.  But that’s Fridman’s style: aggressive, highly-leveraged takeovers, followed by reorganization and then a sale to a strategic investor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Venezuelan troops stormed Mendoza’s Polar bottling plants, after Venezuela president Hugo Chavez accused them of hoarding water, beer and other staples. Despite the upheaval, Mendoza scored a coup in December when he sold his almost 25% share of Peruvian brewery Backus to Colombian brewer, Bavaria, for $568 million. These are just two of the holdings that make up Mendoza’s $3 billion  (revenues) Empresas Polar, founded by his grandfather as a beer company and now one of Venezuela’s largest private companies with interests in everything from tuna fish to condiments to wine. Although intensely private, he and his family occasionally appear in the society pages, mostly in connection with their charitable foundation, Fundación Polar, one of Venezuela&#39s largest.

name: Billionaires
bio: The world’s most eligible bachelor? With his mother and sister, Quandt, 37, controls one of the most powerful family fortunes in Germany today. Inherited 17.4% of BMW (mother and sister own another 29.2%), as well as 77% of power supply equipment maker CEAG. Plus he owns a $634 million (sales) holding company, Delton AG, which last August acquired 45% of midcap logistics company Thiel Logistik AG. Rumors predict he may soon become head of BMW’s supervisory board, of which he and his sister, Susanne, are members.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sneaker giant's stock took dive last February after earnings came in short, but Nike has surged back like a distance runner, hitting a new 52-week high in January. With net worth of $5.7 billion, cofounder Knight hits new high himself; remains chairman, CEO, president and whipping-boy-in-chief for opponents of low-wage manufacturing in Asia. Stopped donating to alma mater U. of Oregon after it joined an antisweatshop organization that it's since left. Knight founded Nike in 1968 with his former track coach, Bill Bowerman (d. 1999), designer of waffle-sole running shoe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Notorious in Japan; claims to be a link between the nation’s gangsters and politicians. Inherited a chain of golf courses from his father. Fortune now includes a $200 million stake in Japan Airlines. Plans to spend $80 million to support nationalist Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara in a bid  to unseat Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party.

name: Billionaires
bio: Edward and his daughter Abigail run Fidelity Investments, nation’s largest mutual fund company, with $770 billion under management, but lately feeling effects of slumping stock market: $100 billion sapped from accounts. With flagship Magellan Fund down 21%, company now playing it more conservatively, pushing new Treasury bond fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1994 sold the last 5% of his Massa chain of German department stores but kept the underlying real estate. Now rents that property to another retailer, Metro. Has other real estate interests: owns several first class properties in New York City, as well as four swank hotels in Switzerland, including the Eden Roc in Ascona, which was named the finest holiday hotel in Switzerland in 2002 by the Swiss magazine Bilan. But he and wife Hannelore prefer to live in their Tschuggen Grand Hotel in Arosa, Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Japan’s leading real estate mogul. Thanks to smart investments, Mori Trust Group has largely survived Japan’s plunging land prices. Bought 10% of Fujita Tourism and 20% of the Loft Department store chain in 2001, and 20% of department store Parco in February 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Marine started out with $10,000 loan, built first house 1958. Acquired sprawling ranch land 1977 with Al Taubman, Max Fisher and Herb Allen (see) for $337 million, later bought out partners. Irvine Co. is Orange County's largest landowner, with some 93,000 acres of property.

name: Billionaires
bio: Latin America’s media baron, owner of  big holdings in Univision, AOL Latin America, DirecTV Latin America and a score of other media companies. An outspoken critic of Venezuela’s President Hugo Chavez,  whom he criticizes for “arrogant abuse of power and authority.” In turn, Chavez accuses him of complicity in last April’s coup attempt and of using his private TV station Venevision to undermine the administration. Luckily, about 80% of his holdings are outside Venezuela. A socialite, Cisneros hobnobs with U.S. friends such as Jimmy Carter and George Bush Sr. Guests at his daughter’s lavish New York wedding reception in October included Kofi Annan, Sid Bass and Oscar de la Renta.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Koch Industries founder Fred Koch. With brother David, inherited holdings after father’s death, today brothers run $35 billion (sales) business: oil services, pipelines, refineries, asphalt, chemicals, ranches. Last year buried the hatchet with litigious brother Bill (see), who claimed he was shortchanged in his inheritance. Koch Industries’ $1 billion deal with Entergy filling energy-trading void left by Enron.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Koch Industries founder Fred Koch. With brother Charles, inherited holdings after father’s death, today brothers run $35 billion (sales) business: oil services, pipelines, refineries, asphalt, chemicals, ranches. Last year buried the hatchet with litigious brother Bill (see), who claimed he was shortchanged in his inheritance. Koch Industries’ $1 billion deal with Entergy filling energy-trading void left by Enron.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of prefab housing manufacturer KB Home and insurer Sun America. Sold latter to AIG in 1998 for $18 billion. Contemporary-art buff (Jasper Johns, Andy Warhol, Jeff Koons), active giver: $400 million pledge to education, $25 million for the new biotech center at California Institute of Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Hollywood studio DreamWorks SKG (see Spielberg, Katzenberg), still mixing it up. With city of Malibu, suing the California Coastal Commission over public access to Malibu beaches. Singled out by Michael Ovitz for bringing about the erstwhile agent's professional demise. More fun battling at box office with Oscar winners A Beautiful Mind, Gladiator, American Beauty. Much of estimated $2 billion nest egg invested with money manager Eddie Lampert (see). Big art collector, recently donated $200 million to UCLA.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns Tengelmann Group, one of Germany’s largest food retailers and one of its largest private companies, with his three sons, Karl-Erivan, Georg and Christian. Holds 57% of A&P supermarkets in the U.S. Tengelmann sales rose to $30 billion in 2001, despite a miserable retail climate in Germany, as the company expanded abroad. America-fan Haub supports St. Joseph’s University in Philadelphia, which named their college of business and administration after him.

name: Billionaires
bio: This private mother-and-son pair successfully hid their fortune until recently. In late 2001 their privately held company, INA Wälzlager Schaeffler KG, which makes roller bearings and engine components, acquired publicly listed FAG Kugelfischer Georg Schäfer, another German maker of roller bearings. The result: $4.6 billion (sales) INA is now a very visible player in the industry. Maria-Elisabeth, age 61, has run the company since her husband’s death in 1996; son Georg, 38, practices international business law at Haynes and Boone in Dallas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heiress to the Heineken fortune, de Carvalho inherited a 25% controlling stake in the world’s third-largest brewer from father Alfred upon his death last year. Charlene has no plans to assume a management role within the company. Lives in London with her investment banker husband, Michel de Carvalho, and their five children. Hobbies include photography, music and architecture. She also boasts membership in Switzerland’s Corviglia Ski Club.

name: Billionaires
bio: In past years, Lee felt the blow of Hong Kong&#39s soft real estate market. The situation only worsened last year. Profits at flagship Henderson Land took a 51% nosedive on a 31.5% sales decline. Lee halted new property development and is now concentrating on rental income. Rentals, which rose 5.5% last year, represent 33% of the group’s revenues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Two-time presidential candidate had to answer to California lawmakers on accusations that his Perot Systems helped energy sellers exploit the state trading system. Company cleared, but stock is down 40%-plus. New 10-year, $392 million Navy contract should help. Founded Electronic Data Systems 1962, sold to General Motors in 1984 for $2.5 billion. Started Perot Systems 1988. Son Ross Jr. now runs Perot Systems, manages familyOs extensive real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: For 20 years, Johnson, 59, has been chairman of Axel Johnson Group, the family owned company founded by her great-grandfather in 1873 and passed on to her by her father. Today the $8.2 billion (revenues) group, which her husband Göran Ennerfelt helps run, has interests in energy, real estate, food retailing and telecommunications. The family holds a 45% share of Stockholm-listed Axfood AB, the third largest food retailer in Sweden. Succession is unclear, as none of her four children are involved in the family business. Other passions: Johnson is an avid horsewoman and a member of numerous Swedish charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner of the eponymous chocolate maker, one of Europe’s largest. Company enjoyed tremendous growth this year. Brands include Ferrero Rocher, Nutella, Tic Tac and Kinder Eggs. Kinder Eggs are banned in the US: the plastic or wooden toys encased in the candy pose a choking hazard. Recently began recruiting managers from outside the company. Passions: church and chocolate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded by father K.C. Irving, the super-secretive Irving family conglomerate operates dozens of companies that together dominate the economy of New Brunswick and maritime Canada. The brothers Irving manage a labyrinthine collection of assets, including Canada’s biggest oil refinery in St. John, 2 million acres of Maine timberland and some 600 filing stations and truck stops. Their Kent Building Supply is looking to stave off Home Depot encroachment in Atlantic Canada. Like Dad, who spent most of his time offshore, the brothers work hard to avoid paying taxes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandfather introduced Wrigley's Spearmint Gum in 1893, added Juicy Fruit, Doublemint. William Jr. took over after father's death in 1999, gave gum business new bite with health-oriented chewing products promoting acid relief, fewer cavities. Stock up 66% since 2000. Controls 28% of the gum maker, but settled family trust dispute over voting shares in August. Also mired in messy divorce with wife, Kandis.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man who earned billions by charming Sam Walton into expanding south of the border. Arango’s retail chain Cifra entered into a joint venture with Wal-Mart in the early 1990s, though the mega-retailer ultimately bought most of Arango’s interests and renamed it Wal-Mex. Spanish-born Arango, who sat on the Wal-Mart board in the late 1990s, is no longer active in either company. Instead he’s been focusing his attention on a luxury resort he’s built up in Acapulco. Doing quite nicely, the resort attracts mainly Mexico City’s smart set.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third fling with studio MGM is rocky: stock down over 40% this year. New James Bond flick may help. Third marriage also a bust; ex-wife Lisa asks for $3.8 million a year in child support, though Kerkorian isn't the natural father. Pursues lawsuit versus DaimlerChrysler over 1998 merger.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sprawling business empire in Asia includes the South China Morning Post, the Shangri-La hotel chain and real estate developer Kerry Properties. Got his start trading rice and then sugar in Malaysia in the 1950s and 60s. Impeccable connections: Former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew was a classmate; Kuok won accolades from the Beijing bosses for not panicking during the Tiananmen Square incident in 1989 While other investors fled, he injected more capital into the China World Trade Center project in downtown Beijing, a showcase joint-venture with the Chinese government.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow and third wife of industrialist Herbert Quandt, who brought BMW back from bankruptcy, lives quietly in the spa town of Bad Homburg near Frankfurt. She owns 16.7% of BMW and retired from its supervisory board in 1997; her children, Susanne and Stephan, own another 29.9%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads the family’s interests, which include Hongkong & Shanghai Hotels and CLP Holdings. CLP, which supplies electricity to more than 5 million people in Hong Kong, has been moving into mainland China. Family business founded more than 100 years ago by Michael’s grandfather, Ellis Kadoorie, a Jew who migrated to Hong Kong from Baghdad.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oversees the family’s private banking and shipping empire founded by father John Latsis. The family’s EFG Bank Group owns a controlling interest in publicly-traded EFG Eurobank Ergasias. While banking accounts for the bulk of the family’s fortune, they continue to stay true to their shipping roots: the fortune includes a modern fleet of oil tankers. There is also a lavish yacht, the Alexander.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father Ted (d. 1999) started Carnival Cruise Lines in 1972; Micky took over 1979 after father moved to Israel. Turned Carnival into the world's largest cruise operator today. Still trying to expand: offered $5 billion for London's P&O Princess Cruises.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandson of Warren Bechtel, who started building railroads in the Oklahoma Territory 1890s. Bechtel now construction and engineering giant: Hoover Dam, nuclear plants, city of Jubail in Saudi Arabia. Revenues: $13.4 billion. Riley current chief, oversees projects like new terminal at O’Hare, London Underground; father Stephen (see) now retired.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Warren Bechtel, who started building railroads in the Oklahoma Territory 1890s. Bechtel now construction and engineering giant: Hoover Dam, nuclear plants, city of Jubail in Saudi Arabia. Revenues: $13.4 billion. Stephen now retired; son Riley (see) current chief, oversees projects like new terminal at O’Hare, London Underground.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inventor's percussion troupe was a critical bust, but his stents and catheters manufacturer a medical marvel. In January, rival Guidant Corp. backed out of deal to buy Cook Group for $3 billion in stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a Buchenwald survivor founded Dassault Aviation, one of France&#39s most prominent military companies. His fortune took a billion-dollar beating this year with the halving in value of his family’s stake in Dassault Systemes, a well-regarded technology company whose fortunes have fallen along with the rest of the sector’s. Meanwhile, as mayor of the Paris suburb of Corbeil-Essonnes, Dassault signed off on the construction of a town Islamic center funded in part by contacts of his in the United Arab Emirates. And the French press continues to beat him up over his hunting excesses, which several years ago resulted in the suspension of his hunting license after he reportedly killed two does and a fawn in three minutes using a truck-mounted, high-powered rifle.

name: Billionaires
bio: With a 25% interest in the Formula One franchise and global viewership off 13%, Ecclestone is desperate for ways to reignite sagging interest in the racing brand. His idea for a pay-per-view service fell flat, when subscribers for the service fell short of what was needed to cover production costs. Now the Formula One Commission is bandying about ways to spice up the sport, rejecting ideas like weight penalties for winning cars, but agreeing to limited qualifiers that put more pressure on racers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Africa’s richest man derives most of his wealth from diamonds. He’s the third generation of his family to head De Beers, a company he took private in 2001 and in which the family owns 45%. Also holds a 3% stake in mining giant Anglo American. He keeps busy in his spare time visiting his farm in Zimbabwe, a game farm in Kalahari region and the Beers mines. He’s also a sports fan and plays cricket, golf and squash. Jonathan Oppenheimer, Nicky’s only child, chairs Element 6, the industrial diamond part of the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-owner, with John Sall, of the world’s largest privately held software company, SAS Institute, ended long flirtation with public offering in wake of recent tech slump. SAS now mining new talent from unemployed techies looking for safer job environment. Despite the duo&#39s best efforts to keep it aloft, side project Midway Airlines grounded for now: carrier bankrupt even after $52 million injection by Goodnight and Sall. Partners met at North Carolina State, started SAS 26 years ago after developing statistical analysis program. Sales now top $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: His grandfather founded Gerling Konzern as a small insurance company in 1904; his father turned it into a major player in the world insurance business. Now Gerling, who owns 65.5% of the company, may have the dubious honor of overseeing its demise. Mismanagement coupled with the Sept. 11 attacks and costly asbestos claims resulted in a $200 million loss last year. Now partner Deutsche Bank, which owns the rest of the company, is pressing for its sale. Gerling, a confirmed environmentalist, apparently cares little about the legacy. He lives in Switzerland, where he heads the Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank that studies the industrial world’s impact on the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Box office performance nearly an ancillary market for the Star Wars producer: video sales of the last Star Wars movies will likely earn the filmmaker more than an estimated $200 million. His Industrial Light & Magic now wrapping up the seriesO final episode.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lord Sainsbury’s net worth has taken a sharp hit with the stock price of the family’s eponymous grocery store—down over 40% in the past year. Blame an industry-wide dowturn. Nonetheless, the grocery chain’s sales and profits have rebounded nicely. Meanwhile, with his share of the company held in a blind trust, Lord Sainsbury’s devoting time to other activities, some controversial.

name: Billionaires
bio: Decorated Navy fighter pilot turned Cadillac salesman after WWII, took 50% pay cut to start own car-leasing business. Enterprise (named after the aircraft carrier he served on during the war) became biggest rental fleet in the business. Sales: $6.3 billion. Son Andrew, 54, now steering company into airport rentals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sole owner of one of Germany’s largest publishing groups, Hubert Burda Media Holding, which produces over 200 titles in 28 different countries. The $2 billion (sales) company has been particularly successful with its award-winning weekly general interest magazine Focus. Also publishes the tabloid Bunte and the German version of Playboy. Also it is the German distributor for Condé Nast magazines such as GQ and Vogue. High-profile Burda sponsors the Hermann-Lenz Prize for German Literature, the Bambi Prize—the German equivalent of the Academy Awards—and a media center at Ben Gurion University in Israel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of steel tycoon John Hartwell Hillman Jr., who built Pittsburgh Coke & Chemical. Henry joined after Princeton, took over in 1959. Invested in light industry, real estate, biotech and technology. Backed Silicon Valley's Kleiner Perkins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-chair of software giant SAP, he is the last of the five cofounders to still have a management role at the company. It may end soon, as rumors swirl predicting he will step down before the end of his contract in 2004. More worrisome for SAP: an agreement among Plattner and two other founders to hold on to their shares (these total 30% of outstanding shares), which recently expired and can now be sold. In the meantime Plattner enjoys his expensive hobbies, including sailing (he got SAP to sponsor the new Zealand sailing team in the America’s Cup) and golfing at the South African luxury hotel and golf course he and his wife, Sabine, own.

name: Billionaires
bio: In a smooth transition that scotched rumors of sibling rivalry, brothers Mukesh and Anil Ambani took charge of the $13.8 billion (revenues) Reliance group, following the death last July of their, father Dhirubhai Ambani, Reliance’s legendary founder. Thanks to last year’s merger of Reliance Petroleum with petrochemicals flagship Reliance Industries, the family’s 34% stake in the combined powerhouse is worth $2.8 billion. Reliance paid $536 million to acquire nearly half of state-owned Indian Petrochemicals and $250 million to take control of BSES, a utility. Keenly awaiting big-ticket privatization of India&#39s state-owned oil refining companies. Recently set off a price war in India’s fast-growing wireless market by launching Reliance India Mobile, a limited mobility phone service, part of Reliance’s ambitious $5 billion telecom project.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Chicago financier Henry Crown (d. 1990), who created Material Service with two brothers in 1919, merged with General Dynamics 1959. Lester controls family holdings, including large stakes in Maytag, Bank One, Rockefeller Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of the mighty Samsung Group had a banner year. Record profits of $4.5 billion on sales of $99 billion made his company the world’s most profitable electronics company in 2002. Still, the Lee family continues to alienate investors and keep the stock price low, due to its archaic and opaque management practices. Despite appearing to own less than 2% of Samsung shares, the family controls the company through a complex series of cross-shareholdings. Lee’s son Lee Jaeyong has been promoted to vice president and is being groomed to succeed his father.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Gallic wheeler-dealer par excellence, Pinault’s ever-rising trajectory from lumber dealer to luxury-retail billionaire looks set for serious turbulence. With his principal holding Pinault-Printemps-Redoute already foundering in debt and preparing for a probable, contractually forced $4.3 billion buyout of Gucci, Pinault has been selling off the company’s crown jewels—most recently its credit card and finance divisions for $3.6 billion. That hasn’t stopped him from hiring Japanese architect Tadao Ando to design the first new museum in Paris in a generation. The Pinault museum, which will be located in a converted Renault factory on an island in the Seine, will house his modern art collection and open later in the decade.

name: Billionaires
bio: Though his net worth has fallen 40% since it’s 1999 high of $4.8 billion, Ebay’s first President and full-time employee is getting by just fine. In October Ebay completed its acquisition of PayPal, a maker of software that enables secures online transactions. By the end of the year Ebay stock had risen 30%. Skoll has endowed his eponymous Skoll Foundation with more than $250 million, which last year alone gave away more than $9 million in grants and loans to entrepreneurial nonprofits worldwide. Skoll’s also an investor in Ovation Entertainment, a southern California film production outfit that will churn movies about social issues and people doing good. Began his fabled career pumping gas in North York, Ontario before getting an M.B.A. from Stanford in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Continues the publishing tradition started by his grandfather in 1875. Today his $1.8 billion (sales) Verlagsgruppe Bauer is one of Germany’s biggest magazine publishers, producing mass media titles like Maxi, popular TV listings and the racy Praline. Bauer recently won bid for the TV and film assets of former billionaire Leo Kirch, which include Europe’s largest film library and about half of Germany’s largest TV broadcaster, ProSiebenSat1. If the deal goes through, it will make him one of the biggest players in European television, rivaling Bertelsmann’s RTL. Ironically, this media magnate is press shy, seldom granting interviews.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked briefly as a doctor before taking over the family bank when his father died in 1948. Built up Banco Real, then sold most of it to ABN AMRO in 1998 for $2.1 billion. Now oversees the remaining assets, called Banco Alfa. Other investments in Brazil include ranch land, soybean farms, hotels, radio stations and a chain of home improvement stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: Got a lot of unwanted attention after American investor Sam Wyly launched a proxy fight for control of Computer Associates in 2001. Haefner, the computer-software giant’s largest individual shareholder, with a 20% stake, helped derail Wyly’s two-year effort by voting against him. Now U.S. federal investigators are investigating Computer Associates’ historical accounting practices. Haefner is still hanging on despite intense pressure to sell. At least his Moyglare Stud Farm in Ireland continues to garner accolades at the track.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of James L. (Bud) Walton (d. 1995), who pooled assets with brother Sam to start Wal-Mart. His stake divided between Ann and sister Nancy Laurie. Ann now married to real-estate developer and sports entrepreneur Stan Kroenke.

name: Billionaires
bio: Raised in Oklahoma, took over family's Kaiser-Francis Oil in 1969. Moved into banking via BOK Financial ($11 billion in assets), but oil and gas exploration still the main engine. Bullish on natural gas, expects prices to peak year-end 2004. Other investments include retirement homes, venture capital, private equity investments. Plans to leave bulk of estate to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger brother Ronald, controls the cosmetics concern started by mother, Estee in 1946. Leonard was chief executive until 1999; now serves as chairman of the board. Today Estee Lauder Companies has 46% of the prestige cosmetics industry with such brands as Estee Lauder, Clinique, M.A.C., Aveda, Bobbi Brown and Stila.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mantegazza’s escorted-tour companies, Globus and Cosmos, faced a rash of cancelations in the wake of the September 2001 terrorist attacks. Yet chief Mantegazza says overall sales were up by 8% in 2001, and expects a 2%-3% increase in 2002. Mantegazza claims profits are steady. Sergio’s father, Antonio, founded the company in 1928 with a boat he used to take tourists around Lake Lugano. Today sales are $2.75 billion, and the company has tours on every continent. Family control over G&C seems assured, Sergio’s sons, Paolo and Fabio, hold senior management positions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left Fairchild Semiconductor 1968 with Robert Noyce and $2.5 million in backing from venture capitalist Arthur Rock to cofound Integrated ElectronicsÑIntel, for short. Now worldOs largest maker of microprocessors, albeit not quite as large as in recent years: 2001 sales down $7 billion. Chairman emeritus holds hefty stake in firm, even after last yearOs massive donation: half of his fortune to Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, philanthropic venture that supports higher education, environmental causes, scientific research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite 25% drop in revenue last year, nation's fourth-largest brokerage still feeling feisty: new ad campaign chides traditional Wall Street shops over conflict-of-interest concerns. Stanford M.B.A. got start writing investment newsletter, founded Schwab as discount brokerage in 1973 with loan from uncle. Purchase of US Trust in 2000 should help lure higher-net-worth clients.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joined his father’s tiny wholesale screw business at age 14, as the company’s second employee. Just five years later, after his father’s sudden death, he took over the business.  In  2001 the company posted sales of $5.6 billion.  Würth retired in 1993. A passionate art collector, he’s amassed more than 6,000 pieces of contemporary art by artists such as Picasso, Alfred Hrdilicka and Christo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third son of Fort Worth oilman Perry Bass showed shrewd timing this year, selling stakes in Mesa Royalty Trusts, San Juan Basin at peak prices. Reinvested some of the proceeds in Florida East Coast Industries. Other investments: Lone Star Technologies, Washington Mutual, Meristar Hotel and Resorts. Yale grad devotes time to historic preservation; joined with brothers (see) for renovation of downtown Fort Worth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Internet retailer regaining momentum after two years of analyst naysaying, investor exodus, sinking stock price. Cheerleading chief says expansion, cost-cutting efforts will push Amazon to profitability. Princeton grad documents daily life via photography.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of $8.5 billion (sales) chemical concern Huntsman Corp. (see story, p. 90).

name: Billionaires
bio: One of four sons of John Elroy McCaw, early investor in cable TV. Second-oldest Craig took over cash-strapped company after father’s death in 1969; sold cable, reinvested in cellular phone networks. Sold McCaw Cellular to AT&T for $11.5 billion in 1993. Brothers dabble in business independently: Craig stayed in telecom, rescued wireless carrier Nextel and founded broadband provider XO Communications. Also funds satellite communications venture Teledesic, but telecom crash making it hard to get business off ground. Finds solace on the high seas: with Paul Allen (see), financed OneWorld Challenge, yacht syndicate competing in the America&#39s Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: The oldest of eight children, he built barns to pay college tuition.  Opened his first home improvement store in 1972. Now Menard's Inc. trying to fend off rapidly expanding competitors Home Depot, Lowe's.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leveraged buyout lover finally ended long slump with sale of Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup. His stake worth $2 billion. Some stock pledged to secure debts, may be for dud deals like Revlon, Sunbeam, Panavision. First big score (excluding fourth wife, Ellen Barkin) since $2.5 billion sale of New World Communications to Fox in 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: An heir of John D. Rockefeller, grain merchant who turned $4,000 investment into Standard Oil. Cornered oil market until broken up 1911 in groundbreaking antitrust case. David headed Chase Bank, founded the Trilateral Commission. Took flak this year for taking $500,000 in federal subsidies for upstate New York soybean farm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited Eternit, a manufacturer of construction materials, following his father’s death in 1984. Decided to sell: bothered by the fact that asbestos, which was a main ingredient in Eternit’s products, was linked to cancer. Reinvested proceeds: was an early investor in what later became Swatch, a bet that netted him about ten times his original investment. Now lets professionals manage his money. Prefers to spend his time trying to incorporate ethical, environmental and social goals into private enterprise. Has donated more than $400 million to the cause. Also funds American abstract art through the Daros Collection, which includes works by Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukrainian-born oil baron studied at the Moscow Institute of Railroad Engineering in the 1970s. Went into business in 1988, teamed up with former classmate who had emigrated to the U.S. in 1990. Led Russia’s first successful hostile takeover in 1994, when his Renova  firm took control of the Vladimir Tractor Factory and installed a Russian-born Harvard M.B.A. to run it. Later bought several medium-size aluminum smelters and bauxite mines, united them into $1 billion (sales) Sual Holding in 1996; now selling 50% stake to foreign investment group. But Vekselberg made the bulk of his fortune when he teamed up with Mikhail Fridman’s Alfa Group to take over TNK, Russia’s third-largest oil company, in 1997-99. This year TNK signed a deal to merge with the Russian operations of BP, giving Vekselberg and other TNK owners $6.75 billion in cash and BP stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israel’s richest resident had an eventful year.  Carnival Cruise, in which she inherited a stake from late father Ted Arison, is close to becoming the largest leisure cruise line in the world. No small feat: Carnival chief executive, Micky Arison (Shari’s brother) beat out Shari’s fellow Israeli billionaires, the Ofer brothers, in a quest to buy P&O Princess Cruise. Newly divorced, Shari also holds a stake in Bank Hapoalim, Israel’s biggest, where she retains a seat on the board. Also owns an interest in Eurocom, Nokia’s exclusive distributor in that country. Arison’s holding company is being bandied in the press as a possible buyer of Bezeq, Israel’s state-owned phone company, which has toyed with privatization for years. Her most active role is in Matan, a charity she founded modelled after the United Way.

name: Billionaires
bio: Considered a worthy inheritor of his late father Aditya’s $4.2 billion (assets) global commodities empire, Birla heads one of India&#39s leading family conglomerates. Combining the group’s metals businesses in flagship Hindalco, he bought an Australian copper mine for $43 million in 2003. Increased stake in Larsen & Toubro, an engineering and cement company, from 10% to 15% and wants more. Keen to diversify into entertainment. The graduate of the London Business School hosts weekly private spiritual discourses at his Malabar Hill residence.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner and honorary chairman of $24 billion (sales) Ito-Yokado retailing group, which includes more than 9,000 7-Elevens in Japan and the U.S., won’t be handing over the company reins to his son, Yasuhisa, 49. The potential successor unexpectedly resigned from the company last year to “study something new.” Meanwhile, 7-Eleven celebrated its 30th anniversary last year by handing out free slurpees. Its supermarket chain, Ito-Yokado, managed to eke out a small increase in sales and profits but could face stiff new competition from foreign retailers like Wal-Mart.

name: Billionaires
bio: Seagram spirits scion must be woozy watching his once formidable fortune evaporate. After son Edgar Jr. took over in 1994, Seagram quickly changed from profitable beverage giant into erratically profitable entertainment company. Sold Tropicana juice business, big stake in DuPont, to help finance acquisitions of MCA/Universal, PolyGram. Sold to Vivendi in 2000 for $34 billion. Family's shares, worth $6.6 billion at the time of the deal, now worth $630 million. Whiskey unlikely to dull the pain.

name: Billionaires
bio: The music world’s most famous recluse is now one of the richest. Last year BMG cut him a $2.7 billion check for his Zomba Recordings, much of which he personally pocketed. The South African-born mogul is the man who benefited most from the teen music craze: Britney Spears, ’N Sync, and the Backstreet Boys all recorded their bubblegum pop for his label. Raised in a middle-class neighborhood in Johannesburg, Calder started out playing bass guitar in local bands, then worked as a scout for EMI records. Formed Zomba in 1971, immigrated to London four years later, the U.S. in 1978.

name: Billionaires
bio: The notoriously press-shy heir to the Campbell Soup fortune fled the U.S. for Ireland in 1994 to avoid taxes. Beside a modest red brick home in Dublin, Dorrance boasts a pied-à-terre in the Bahamas and one in Wyoming. Resurfaced in the early 1990s to unsuccessfully pressure Wyoming legislators to legalize game ranching for native and exotic wildlife. The bid failed, and with it his plans to raise imported sheep, boar, elk and wolf.

name: Billionaires
bio: The last of Japan’s electronics tycoons, his Funai Electric is doing surprisingly well, with sales up 42% year for the first six months of fiscal year 2002, which ended in September. A leading manufacturer of cheap TVs, VCRs and DVD players is on target to double sales to $4.2 billion by 2005. The company has been a pioneer in manufacturing in China since 1992 and is a leading supplier of electronics sold by Wal-Mart under the Emerson brand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oldest child of the second family of Texas oil magnate H.L. Hunt (d. 1974), inherited most of Hunt Oil Co. with three sisters. Aggressive wildcatter scored big, while half-siblings, led by Bunker Hunt, went bust in silver market. Holds big stakes in Canadian natural gas fields; also deals in Peru, Togo, Yemen, Oman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish-born cook, former chambermaid struck gold in 1971 when she married Johnson & Johnson founder's son, John Seward Johnson (d. 1983). "Basia" inherited large chunk of J&J stock and the deed to the sprawling N.J. estate, Jasna Polana ("bright meadow" in Polish). Now operated as a private golf club.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built his empire on the strength of contracting deals with the Saudi government. Expanded into banking and real estate before venturing into media, his true passion. Founded MBC (Middle East Broadcasting Center) and ART (Arab Radio & Television), the latter a chronic moneyloser and cash drain. Owns a majority of Dallah Albaraka, a conglomerate that runs vast Islamic banking operations, as well as real estate, construction and manufacturing interests. The ailing Islamic banking business is undergoing a massive overhaul. Like many wealthy Saudis, Kamel confronts allegations that some of his business interests may have been exploited by terrorist elements. Kamel denies any wrongdoing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Lego, the toy company he inherited in 1979. Company founded in 1932, when grandfather Ole Kirk, a carpenter, started making wooden toys in the village of Billund, Denmark. The forerunner of the plastic brick came after the company invested in a plastic injection-moulding machine in 1947. Since then, the company has sold more than 320 billion Lego bricks. In July the company teamed up with Miramax to produce an animated motion picture scheduled for a 2004 release.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Bud Walton (d. 1995), who went in with his brother Sam to start up Wal-Mart. Massive hoard of shares split with sister Ann Kroenke. Husband Bill owns NHL's St. Louis Blues after losing out to brother-in-law Stan Kroenke in bidding for Colorado Avalanche. Lauries also breed horses on 350-acre Crown Center Farms.

name: Billionaires
bio: Talent agent in the 1960s; represented Marlon Brando, Liz Taylor. Formed production house Embassy Communications with producer Norman (All in the Family) Lear 1974; sold to Coca-Cola 1985 for $485 million. With partners bought Spanish-language broadcaster Univision for $550 million 1992. Took public 1996; stake now worth $1 billion. Added second Spanish-language network, Telefutura, in January. Pending bid to acquire Spanish-language radio powerhouse Hispanic Broadcasting for $3.5 billion. Producer at heart, companyOs developing telenovelas for Univision. Big donor to Democrats and Republicans.

name: Billionaires
bio: Corporate lawyer turned family's oil and gas fortune into luxury hotel chain. Spent big on Omni Hotels despite weak market: $110 million on historic San Francisco hotel, $70 million on Atlanta property. "I guess it's a contrarian strategy." Joined dad's Tana Oil & Gas in 1972; sold production units to Texaco in 1989, exploration division to Unocal. Now drilling in Gulf of Mexico, New Zealand, offshore Texas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has come a long way from his start as an apprentice butcher. His 10,000 American-style drugstores are the Walgreens of Germany, selling everything from soap to sweets. The Anton Schlecker company has $6.6 billion in sales (2001) and a 45% share of the drugstore sector. Success has its price: In December 1987 his two children, Lars and Meike, were kidnapped and later released after he paid a $6 million ransom. Now they run the company's Internet site.

name: Billionaires
bio: Near bankruptcy of Vivendi spelled bad year for Bronfman clan. Since selling Seagram to the French media giant in 2000, Charles and nephew Edgar, Jr. have lost a combined $3.6 billion. After helping oust Vivendi chief Jean-Marie Messier, Charles cut his losses. Vivendi stake now less than $300 million. Still the Bronfmans press on. Last year his children launched Charles Bronfman Prize, granting $100,000-a-year endowment to those doing most to advance Jewish causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Location, location, location. Decaux has spent the past four decades slapping advertisements on bus-stop shelters, public toilets and billboards in bustling cities like Hong Kong and Paris. Next stop, North America. In the last two years Decaux has secured contracts with the cities of Chicago, Los Angeles and Vancouver, B.C. (the latter two in coalition with Viacom). This year his eponymous company bids for New York City. Founder Jean-Claude Decaux chairs the supervisory board, while sons, Jean-François and Jean-Charles run the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Leonard, controls the cosmetics concern started by mother, Estee, in 1946. Ronald a non-executive director. Today Estee Lauder Companies has 46% of the prestige cosmetics industry, with such brands as Estee Lauder, Clinique, M.A.C., Aveda, Bobbi Brown and Stila. Chairman of RSL Communications, which recently filed for bankruptcy.

name: Billionaires
bio: This steel titan oversees LNM Group, the world’s second-largest steelmaker. Among its holdings is Ispat International, which posted $4.5 billion in sales in 2001. Business is booming. LNM recently acquired steel plant Nova Hut in the Czech Republic, and will up its stake in South African Iscor to 47%. LNM’s steel mills span 12 countries, including the U.S., Canada, Mexico, France, Germany, Kazakhstan, Romania and Algeria. Son Aditya is LNM Holdings vice-chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: This former car salesman married his childhood sweetheart, took out a $40,000 bank loan to buy a Buick and Pontiac franchise in British Columbia and made and lost a fortune before building a second one. His Jim Pattison Group conglomerate is worth $2.2 billion, with interests in billboards, grocery stores and packaging. Also owns Ripley’s Believe it or Not!, an international chain of 44 oddball attractions that include curiosities like a 23-foot-tall model of the Eiffel Tower made entirely of toothpicks, and a spitting image of the Mona Lisa, made of 63 pieces of toast.

name: Billionaires
bio: Major shareholder of Barr Laboratories and Apotex, generic drug makers and perennial thorns in the side of pharmas like Eli Lilly and AstraZeneca. Cangene, majority-owned by Apotex, scored a $40 million contract with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in August to manufacture an antibody for the smallpox vaccine. Déjà vous? Two years ago Sherman tussled with Bayer when his company was ordered by Canada’s health minister to produce a million tabs of its generic antianthrax drug. Bayer, which holds patent for Cipro, threatened to sue both parties. All three parties reached an out-of-court agreement—Bayer stores the generics, and Apotex won’t charge the government for its pills unless they are used. Latest battle: litigation with GlaxoSmithKline, maker of antidepressant Paxil, over marketing generic relief.

name: Billionaires
bio: The future wasn't so bright for Hollywood's Midas: Orwellian thriller, Minority Report, and robo-kid flick, A.I.: Artificial Intelligence, did so-so at the box office. Hopes to do better with next film, Catch Me If You Can, starring Tom Hanks and heartthrob Leonardo DiCaprio. Past blockbusters: Jaws, E.T., Raiders of the Lost Ark, Jurassic Park.

name: Billionaires
bio: Manhattan's ultrahip Soho Grand and Tribeca Grand hotels are gems in developer's real estate empire, but crown jewel is 35 million square feet of commercial space in New Jersey, mostly in the Meadowlands. With children focused on real estate and investments, sold non-real-estate assets like the Village Voice and Hartz Mountain pet-supply business, company his German immigrant father started with 5,000 canaries in 1926.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of four brothers, he owns the largest personal stake in the family’s Al Rajhi Banking and & Investment Corp., which operates under Islamic principles, paying no interest on deposits. He’s also the most active of the brothers, acting as the bank’s chairman and managing director. Both Al Rajhi and the bank have been named in the trillion-dollar lawsuit filed by families of victims of the September 11 attacks, accused of financing terrorist activities. The bank denies the charges. Al Rajhi also boasts his country&#39s largest poultry farm, a building-materials business and real estate. He reportedly has fathered at least 23 children.

name: Billionaires
bio: The U.K.’s second-richest landowner, Earl Cadogan filed a suit last year blocking a luxury development on land his grandfather had sold over fifty years ago, on the grounds that the land was intended for the benefit of the “working class.” The landmark case has drawn enormous publicity, in part because its outcome could place thousands of working-class London homes, situated on prime property, in jeopardy. (There’s also the irony in Cadogan, the nation’s fifth-richest resident, taking up the cause.) Massive preparations are also underway to commemorate 250 years of the the Cadogan estates.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of oil titan J. Paul Getty (d. 1976) sold Getty Oil to Texaco for $10 billion in 1986. Now composes operas, makes wine; pillar of San Francisco society, big benefactor of Los Angeles Opera and Philharmonic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband Bronson Ingram inherited disparate empire: oil refining, inland marine transportation. Added books; became big distributor of computers, videotapes. Martha inherited fortune after Bronson's death in 1995; took Ingram Micro public a year later. Three sons run other, privately held Ingram Industries, Ingram Entertainment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ohio State law school dropout opened first Limited outlet 1963 with $5,000 loan after upset with father over small family department store. Now 5,300 stores generate over $8 billion in sales, down 2%. Intimate Brands recently folded back into Limited; Lane Bryant sold in $335 million deal.  Current brands: Victoria&#39s Secret, Bath & Body Works, Express, Express Men&#39s (Structure), Lerner New York, Limited Stores, White Barn Candle Co., Henri Bendel. Spin-offs: Abercrombie & Fitch 1998, Limited Too 1999. Art enthusiast Wexner bought and donated $45 million “Nude on a Black Armchair” by Picasso.

name: Billionaires
bio: The chief executive of Mashreqbank is a well-known, vocal proponent of anti-money-laundering laws in the Middle East. Also owns shopping malls and a cement company. An industrial engineer by training, Al Ghurair graduated with honors from the California Polytechnic State University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable pioneer prefers to operate behind the scenes, but still active in industry: said to be potential buyer for bruised Adelphia cable outfit. Founded Continental Cablevision in 1963, sold to US West in 1996. Renamed MediaOne, sold to AT&T three years later for $58 billion. Hostetter returned as board member at AT&T; filled top spots with former Continental employees. But with cable stocks out of favor, personal wealth down 20% in the last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Koc Holding, Turkey’s largest and oldest conglomerate, maker of Ford cars and color TVs. Strong demand for automotive and durable goods helped him meet his export target of $2.6 billion last year, a 45% increase over the year before. Also bolstered by growth of Arcelik division, one of Europe’s largest manufacturers of household appliances. Named a nonrelative to chief executive, but son Mustafa remains vice chairman. Visit to Henry Ford Museum in Michigan inspired Koc to create the Rahmi M. Koc Museum in Istanbul which exhibits trains, submarines and autos.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of International Data Group getting tossed about in the tech storm. Recent ad slump affecting magazines (PC World, Computerworld), trade shows (Macworld), online endeavors. IDG employees feeling less pain than most techies, thanks to generous profit sharing, PatOs paternalism: personally delivers greeting cards to all of IDGOs 1,100 U.S. employees.

name: Billionaires
bio: The low-profile construction magnate and real estate developer left college to work in privately owned family business. Shrewdly expanded inheritance by getting lucrative contracts in India and overseas, mainly Muscat. Mistry is also the largest individual shareholder in Tata Sons, holding company of the $9.4 billion Tata group, India’s leading business conglomerate. With his 18.4% stake, worth $1.6 billion, and his daughter’s marriage to Tata scion Noel, is expected to have say appointing the successor of group chairman Ratan Tata. Keeps homes in Mumbai, Dubai and London. The devout Parsi prays daily. According to a family spokesman, Mistry wouldn’t share details of assets with FORBES because “he doesn’t need you to tell him he’s rich!”

name: Billionaires
bio: AOL Time Warner’s largest shareholder – and biggest mouth – resigned as vice-chairman of the board after the media giant posted a record $98.7 billion loss. Still sits on the board, but reportedly looking at partnering with Sumner Redstone or Bill Gates to make a play for AOL Time Warner assets - including his beloved but faltering CNN. Or maybe he’ll just stick to running Ted’s Montana Grill, his chain bison-meat restaurants. Commentary outside the boardroom equally incendiary: jeopardized CNN contracts with three Israeli cable operators after likening nation&#39s recent military operations in Palestinian territory to terrorism. Even though AOL stake down 60% this year, still plans to honor $1 billion pledge to the United Nations.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of three children of father Joyce Hall (d. 1982), who started selling postcards out of Kansas City YMCAs as teenager. Today privately held Hallmark sells more than half of all greeting cards in U.S. Sour economy prompted debut of office-life cards, including those for laid-off co-workers. Also hired poet Maya Angelou to pen line of inspirational cards.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his father’s business, which specialized in dust removal, into publicly listed GEA. In 1999 sold his stake to engineering company MG Technologies for $1 billion in cash and stock and retired to tax paradise Switzerland to run Luserve AG, a financial consulting firm. But recently he has again become involved in his family’s business, as an agitated shareholder: He has been attempting to sue MG’s chairman, accusing him of mismanagement, high losses and false accounting. To no avail: The courts dismissed the suit as self-serving and not in the best interest of the company (the bickering was having a depressing effect on share prices). He can always retreat to Fregate Island, a luxury tourist paradise in the Seychelles, which he reportedly owns.

name: Billionaires
bio: Launched Polo in 1967 with $50,000, transformed men's clothing line into brand behemoth; now sells clothes for men, women and children, as well as fragrances, linens, paint and accessories. Collects antique cars and motorcycles; owns homes in New York, Colorado and Jamaica.

name: Billionaires
bio: Contrarian investor rewarded with post-Sept. 11 bet on catastrophe insurer PXRE Group: investment up 60%. "I look for great moments to enter a business, and that's usually when it's on its back." Got start managing Bass familyOs $50 million portfolio 1970, including big Disney stake in 1984. Broke out on his own two years later. "I'm just a retired guy who made a couple billion by being in the right place at the right time."

name: Billionaires
bio: Controlling shareholder of Holcim, a large cement supplier. Temporarily resigned under pressure as chairman of Holcim amid legal investigations into his private purchase of shares in a formerly listed Spanish company. In February, decided not to resume the chairmanship, but as principal shareholder remains a board member.
