Has a master’s in Mechanical Engineering from the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich and an M.B.A. from IMD in Lausanne, Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helped father restore foundering Bank of North Carolina before merging with NCNB 1982. Renamed NationsBank, merged with BankAmerica to form Bank of America; now controls 16 million shares. Also owns National Gypsum, real estate through C.D. Spangler Construction. Former president of University of North Carolina now tinkers with grandfather clocks: "There's not much competition in that." Daughter Anna runs venture capital firm Wakefield Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made it big on cigarettes and liquor in the Philippines. Forays into banking and aviation are proving to be more challenging: His three-year effort to revive Philippine National Bank still ongoing while Philippine Airlines has only managed to eke out two consecutive years of profits since he took control in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Minnesota farm boy worked way through college at print shop. Convinced retiring owner to sell for $2 million over 10 years. Paid off early, built Taylor Corp., a $1.3 billion (sales) printing, electronics business. Retired as CEO, still chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: It wouldn't quite be The Forbes 400 if The Donald didn't disagree with our net worth estimate: "You've got way the wrong number." Condo sales strong at his residential buildings, other deals also rolling in: purchased Delmonico Hotel in Manhattan for $115 million; planning 87 mansions on new Trump golf course in Westchester County, N.Y. Crown jewel: 40 Wall Street, bought for $1 million, ahead of real estate boom, now worth hundreds of times that. Long-term leases keeping Wall Street's turmoil from affecting value. "All of my stuff has been fantastic." Not quite: publicly held Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts laden with debt, unprofitable since 1993.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the five founders of German software powerhouse SAP. Trained physicist Tschira devotes his time to his Klaus Tschira Foundation, located in the Villa Bosch, once home to German Nobel Prize-winning chemist Carl Bosch. The nonprofit is dedicated to scientific and cultural projects. An amateur astronomer, Tschira has a small asteroid named after him.

name: Billionaires
bio: World War II veteran made fat fortune helping others slim down. Bought Thompson Medical in 1947 and sold it 51 years later for a reported $200 million profit; then Slim-Fast, weight-loss-supplement maker. Sold to Unilever for $2.3 billion in 2000. Big giver to Democrats, Israel. Fitness nut says health trumps wealth: "Having more money or less money doesn't add or detract from your living."

name: Billionaires
bio: Tanking media stocks meant no big deals germinated at Allen's annual confab in Sun Valley, Idaho. Board member, big investor in Coca-Cola; the beverage company's board approved expensing stock options at the conference.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Sankyo, a major manufacturer of pachinko slot machines. The company scored an industry coup last year when it acquired two leading manufacturers of prepaid cards for pachinko machines. The pachinko industry overall, however, is in a slump as penny-pinching Japanese citizens gamble less.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third-generation grocer feeds yuppie tastes with upscale Central Market stores, which eschew brands like Kraft and Coca-Cola in favor of gourmet foods, wine and cheese, in-store cafes. Today 300 H.E. Butt stores generate $9 billion in sales. Former bag boy (and Wharton grad) donates 5% of pretax profit to charities, much of it to public education.

name: Billionaires
bio: San Francisco lawyer planted 20 acres of grapes in 1974, sold first wine in 1982. Marketed modestly priced chardonnay and cabernet, turned Kendall-Jackson into one of America's biggest winemakers: $410 million sales, 4.5 million cases of wine shipped. Put company on the block in late 2000 but rejected 3 offers of $1.7 billion. Now investing in Australia and Chile via Yangarra Park and Calina brands.

name: Billionaires
bio: The shopping mall Midas. As executive chairman and founder of Westfield Holdings, Lowy heads up a $17.3 billion shopping center portfolio that includes 111 shopping centers on three continents, with more than 8 million square meters of retail space and 16,700 retailers. Also held a 99-year lease on the World Trade Center’s subterranean retail plaza. Now he’s pressing for consideration in the contentious debate over development of the new site. Perhaps he’ll fare better than he did in a recent skirmish he is rumored to have had with a Melbourne neighbor. Lowy unsuccessfully petitioned to stop the interloper from expanding a terrace Lowy feared would invade his privacy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Power struggle for McCain Foods has led to strained relations with billionaire brother Harrison. Wallace left McCain Foods, ultimately taking over meat processor Maple Leaf Foods in 1995. Profits in the third quarter increased a healthy 33%. Still, bad blood runs deep between the brothers. Wallace’s daughter is aspiring singer Eleanor McCain, who waxed about the long-standing feud in her 2001 debut album.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former Soviet foreign trade official, Potanin teamed up with banker Mikhail Prokhorov in 1992 to take over the assets of two Soviet-era foreign trade banks. Later won control of metals giant Norilsk Nickel and oil company Sidanco in controversial “loans-for-shares” auctions. Served as deputy prime minister in charge of the economy in 1996-97; then partnered with George Soros to invest in telecom monopoly Svyazinvest, but sold Soros his stake after the two had a falling out. The devaluation of the ruble in 1998 forced the liquidation of his Uneximbank; Potanin sold his oil interests to Mikhail Fridman’s Alfa Group soon after. Now focusing on running Norilsk and investing in agriculture. Joined the board of the Guggenheim Museum last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Succeeded father as head of $14 billion (sales) Dogus conglomerate in 2001. A rough ride so far. Turkey’s economic woes helped depress value of his Garanti Bank and car distributor Dogus Oto. Still, Sahenk successfully restructured his media operations and lowered costs at Tansas supermarket chain. In June he became the first Turk to join the advisory council of MIT’s Sloan School of Business, and he is even the subject of a Harvard Business School case study. In his off-hours Sahenk takes black-and-white photos with a Leica camera.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tsai Wan Tsai may be new to our list this year but he’s not exactly a new billionaire. Until this year his assets have been counted as part of his brother Tsai Wan Lin’s financial services fortune. But the two brothers, who supposedly started out in soy and vinegar manufacturing parted back back in the late 1980s. Today the two are friendly rivals: Wan Tsai controls Fubon Financial Holdings; his brother Cathay Financial Holdings. These days the 74-year-old takes a back seat to his U.S.-educated sons, Richard and Daniel Tsai, who run the day-to-day operations. Both are gearing up Fubon’s competitiveness, selling a 15% stake (since diluted to 11%) to Citigroup and most recently acquiring TaipeiBank. Fubon is now Taiwan’s second-largest financial holding company.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Gravedancer" probably wishing he stuck with trademark bargain-hunting: his Equity Office Properties paid big last year to buy San Francisco office developer Ned Spieker's REIT, solidifying Equity as the country's largest office REIT. With Silicon Valley awash in vacancies and canceled leases, Equity Office shares mired at 1997 levels.

name: Billionaires
bio:
In January 2001 long-simmering rivalry between Günter and his three brothers forced him to step down after almost 35 years of successful leadership of Tchibo Holding, one of Germany’s largest concerns. A nonfamily member now manages the company. Last May the family stopped squabbling long enough to sell their 75.1% stake in Reemtsma Cigarettes to  Imperial Tobacco for $4 billion. The speculation is that the family would like to use the money from the tobacco sale to increase their present 27.6% share of Nivea-producer Beiersdorf and acquire majority control. At least Gunter can take comfort in his 20.6% stake in the family fortune, slightly larger than his siblings’ stakes. An avid fan of race horses, he can now spend more time at the trotter stud farm he owns in Schleswig-
Holstein.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thumbing his nose at the global downturn: his Armani Group continues its fast pace store openings—30 new locations added in 2002 including a flagship store in Hong Kong, the company’s launch pad into China; acquires knitwear maker Deanna and shoe maker Guardi; and launches Emporio Armani Jewellery. Spent two years in medical school before dropping out in 1957 to accept a job as a buyer at a department stores. Named Goodwill Ambassador by United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in May for his fund raising and public awareness efforts on behalf of the organization.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bailleres reigns over a far-flung commercial empire in Mexico, with holdings ranging from the world’s biggest silver producer to a successful department store chain to a major insurance company. And he does it well. In a year when most fortunes shrank, Bailleres’ expanded, largely on the strength of his mining operations. Something of a throwback, Bailleres is passionate about bullfighting and horse racing.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Photo-Op King donned little more than a flesh-colored bodysuit and an oversized cell phone (hung fig-leaf style) last summer for a Times Square striptease with the cast of Broadway’s Full Monty. The event, and a much-hyped partnership with MTV, marked the launch of Virgin Mobile cellular service in the U.S. This wasn’t Branson’s only stunt last year. In November he held a mock Indian ceremony, even smoking a peace pipe, to celebrate a truce reached with Sydney Airport, which finally leased space to discount carrier Virgin Blue after interminable negotiations. Branson hopes to float his 50% stake in the airline as early as May, an unusual move for the man who has shunned the stock market since a disastrous two-year run of Virgin Group on the London exchange in the mid 1980s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cheng’s listed flagship New World Development took another beating this year. The company’s share price declined a further 47%, evaporating some $300 million from his fortune. But Cheng seems unperturbed, announcing plans to build Hong Kong’s tallest hotel at a cost of some $220 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Desmarais bought his father’s one-route Ontario bus company for a buck in 1951, parlaying it into Power Corp., an $12.1 billion (sales) financial services and communications titan. A Power Corp. consortium bought an indirect 25% stake in media giant Bertelsmann in early 2001. Desmarais also owns Investors Group, Canada’s largest group of mutual funds. Thanks to its diversification, Power Corp. held its price despite a $128 million Sept. 11-related writedown. While sons Andre and Paul Jr. run the company, Paul Sr. collects Canadian art and bird hunts on his private estate in Quebec.

name: Billionaires
bio: With high school pal Jay Van Andel (see), partnered in drive-in eatery, nutritional supplement sales before starting Amway 1959. Today over 3 million sales reps worldwide sell personal care, home products. Sales in 2001: $4.1 billion. Retired, Amway reorganized under Alticor. Owns NBA’s Orlando Magic.

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout started Waste Management in 1962 with one used garbage truck. Bought 19-store Blockbuster Video chain 1984; expanded, sold to Viacom 10 years later for $8.4 billion. Now runs AutoNation, world's largest new and used car dealer. Got big boost from recent investment by money manager Eddie Lampert (see). Owner of pro football's Miami Dolphins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apple Computer has just 5% market share, but owns near-monopoly on buzz for cool gear like MP3 player iPod, table-lamp-like iMac computer. Eternal optimist plans to jump-start sluggish growth by making Apple center of Odigital lifestyle.O Founded Apple 1976 with Steve Wozniak. Formed Next Computer after ouster from Apple 1985; returned when Apple bought Next 1996 for $400 million. Catalyst for next generation OS. Name synonymous with Apple, but bulk of wealth hitched to animated film studio Pixar (Monsters, Inc., Toy Story). Good thing: for the year Apple shares down 32%; Pixar up 34%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father James joined specialty investment firm in 1945. Peter became director in 1973, sold Spear, Leeds & Kellogg to Goldman Sachs for $5.7 billion in 2000. Made killing on side investments in mid-1990s (Alex. Brown, National Discount Brokers); owns large stakes in a handful of smaller companies, mostly finance and technology. Chairman of Wisconsin investment firm Ziegler Companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Campbell Soup accountant joined pet food entrepreneur Paul Iams in 1970. Bought out partner in 1982; created high-end market selling premium puppy chow. Sold Iams Co. to Procter & Gamble in 1999 for $2.3 billion. Family foundation funds projects in Ohio, educational initiatives in Guatemala.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helped her husband, Spain’s richest man Amancio Ortega, found hugely successful Zara clothing chain. Early years spent working out of their home. Now divorced, she is on the parent company Inditex’s board and holds a 7% share, making her Spain’s richest woman. She is president of the Paideia Foundation, which helps the disabled, and sits on the board of Zeltia, a Spanish chemical company that is looking for cancer treatments in compounds found in the sea.

name: Billionaires
bio: A busy year for Sir Kenneth, who sparked a six-way takeover contest when he put in an all-stock $3.7 billion bid for Safeway, Britain’s fourth-largest supermarket chain. It’s no sure thing. While sales and profits for Morrison’s supermarket chain went up last year, the 35th year in a row, the company’s stock has sunk 16% since his early January bid announcement. What’s more, fellow Brit big shot Philip Green also expressed an interest in buying Safeway. Another blow: Longtime managing director John Dowd, rumored to be Morrison&#39s successor, died in March 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime music promoter in Israel moved to Los Angeles, created cartoon hit Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. Sold to Rupert Murdoch for share of Fox Family Worldwide; snared biggest cash payout in Hollywood last year, $1.5 billion, with network's sale to Disney. Big Democratic donor gave record $7 million earlier this year for new party headquarters. Strong supporter of Israel; funded Saban Center for Middle East Policy at Brookings Institution.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Keyence, a leading manufacturer of sensors. The company has been performing reasonably well, with sales and profits up 4% and 14%, respectively. Sales of sensors and factory automation equipment to Europe and Asia, especially China, did particularly well.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made fortune saving conglomerate Morrison Knudsen in 1996, but then hit rocky times last year when renamed Washington Group filed Chapter 11. Also owns CanadaOs largest tug-and-barge company, yachts, British Columbia island with golf course. Donated 64,000-acre ranch in Oregon for underprivileged youth.

name: Billionaires
bio: With husband Donald, opened the first Gap store in 1969 in San Francisco, added or acquired brands including BabyGap, Old Navy, Banana Republic. The chain is grappling with growth pains and falling profits: The Fisher family is no longer in day-to-day control after departure of sons William and Robert from executive ranks, but Donald remains chairman and Doris remains a member of the board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Buyout specialist migrated with family from Israel 1968. Worked with brother Tom (see) until 1995 split. Brothers now neighbors in LA, compete for deals. Alec's Gores Technology Group has made 40 acquisitions, generates $4 billion in revenues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Publicity-shy Gou (sometimes known as Kuo) reportedly described his company's 57% increase in revenues in 2001 as a ?lonely goose flying in a chilly winter.?  While the goose, Hon Hai Precision, is still flying high, the economic winter has given Guo a chill. Made predictions that last year's revenues would grow an additional 43%, but reportedly shelved plans to issue $1.4 billion in stocks and bonds.

name: Billionaires
bio: A year after walking away with $1.9 billion from Citigroup’s buyout of Mexican banking powerhouse Banamex, Roberto Hernandez is burnishing his cultural credentials and enjoying the good life. Recently returned from long vacations in London and Rome, Hernandez still chairs the board of Banamex and retains a seat on Citigroup’s board. He’s also chairman of Mexico’s National Museum of History and spends his free time fixing up old cotton haciendas in Mexico’s Yucatan peninsula.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest child and only daughter of late coffee magnate Max Herz and his wife, Ingeburg. Her fortune comes from her 19% stake in the family’s holdings, which include 100% of one of Germany’s largest private companies, Tchibo Holding, 27.6% of Nivea-maker Beiersdorf, and $4 billion in cash from the 2001 sale of Reemtsma cigarettes to Imperial Tobacco. Apparently sided with brother Günter in the siblings’ very public feud for management of the fortune. Didn’t help him: He stepped down in early 2001.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime real estate syndicator started Private Storage 1972 in California after noticing full storage shed in Texas. Changed name to Public Storage when customer asked if space was open to public. Took public 1995. Today 800,000 self-storage spaces generate $835 million in revenues.

name: Billionaires
bio: So far this former oil trader has managed to defy the odds and come up on top. Despite the bleak outlook for the global telecom sector and the discovery of terrorist cells in Malaysia, he orchestrated a successful listing of his mobile phone provider Maxis last year. His companies, which include satellite TV and racetrack betting, are admired for being among the best-managed in Asia. Has aspirations to expand: he has unveiled plans to launch three satellites, starting in 2004, and to step up marketing efforts in Hong Kong, India and South Africa. Has an M.B.A. from Harvard.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads the Lee clan’s fortune, which includes one of the island nation’s leading banks, the Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation. Management of the bank left to professionals, Lee devotes his time to philanthropic activities: The family’s Lee Foundation is a big supporter of education in Asia. Lee holds a Bachelor of Applied Science from the University of Toronto and an M.B.A. from the University of Western Ontario.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother-and-sister team sits atop Liebherr Group, a major maker of construction cranes, with more than $3.7 billion in annual sales. Company founded in 1949 by father Hans Liebherr, who invented a crane to simplify the task of postwar building in Europe. Today company also produces aircraft parts, refrigerators and excavators.

name: Billionaires
bio: As part of their estate planning, the Ofer brothers are dividing the empire, to be finalized this year. Monaco-based Sammy and his children will control the international shipping assets and Israel Corp., which owns Zim Navigation, as well as oil refineries in Israel. Israel-based Yuli and his kids will retain the vast real estate holdings, including several shopping malls, marinas, and office complexes. Sammy, who counts several works by Marc Chagall among his vast contemporary art collection, is a major donor of college scholarships in his country.

name: Billionaires
bio: Argentina’s lone billionaire scored a big coup in October when he announced the sale of the family’s 60% share of Petrolera Perez Companc, Argentina’s largest energy company, to Brazilian oil giant Petróleo Brasileiro S.A. (Petrobras) for a reported $1 billion in cash and bonds. The family also has a 68% share of Molinos Rio de la Plata, one of Argentina’s leading processed-foods companies. Known for his love of modern and vintage cars: reportedly owns a Bugatti, a Maserati and a limited-edition Ferrari F-50.

name: Billionaires
bio: Moscow State Financial Institute graduate worked in one of the big Soviet foreign trade banks; teamed up with Vladimir Potanin to take over the assets of two foreign trade banks being liquidated. The venture, later named Interros, grew through the 1990s to include oil, metals, engineering and telecommunications; since 2001, Prokhorov has been chairman of its most valuable holding, metals conglomorate Norilsk Nickel. The only Russian billionaire who is a bachelor, Prokhorov is often featured in gossip columns about blow-out parties on the French Riviera. But then it’s back to work at his metals plant on the Arctic Circle.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gummi Bear heir. He and his brother Paul closely guard their father’s 1922 recipe for delicious gummi bears, cola bottles and licorice wheels. The result: Their privately held candy company Haribo GmbH, which makes 80 million gummi bears each day, has $1.6 billion in sales and a 60% share of the German candy market. A ripe 80, Hans Jr., who is unmarried and has no children, continues to run the company and develop new products, while brother Paul oversees production and technical issues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fled Hungary for New York in 1958 at age 13. Studied economics at UCLA, became avid flier. Along with Louis and his father Leslie Gonda (see both), started International Lease Finance Corp with $150,000 and a $1.7 million bank loan. Bought in 1990 by insurance giant AIG for stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ethiopian-born and raised in Saudi Arabia, Al Amoudi made his fortune in construction and real estate before branching out to buy oil refineries in Sweden and Morocco. The largest foreign investor in both Sweden and his native Ethiopia, he is currently expanding his African investments through the AIG Africa Infrastructure Fund. Lately, Al-Amoudi has been busy defending himself after being named a terrorist financier in the trillion-dollar lawsuit filed by the families of 9/11 victims. Through a spokesperson he denies ever having financed any terrorist efforts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bag boy founded investment firm Yucaipa in 1986, did leveraged buyouts of grocery chains Jurgensen's, Ralphs, Dominick's, Fred Meyer. This year bagged buddy Bill Clinton to consult for new $1.5 billion fund planning to bring companies to rural and inner-city areas. Recent investment in bankrupt retailer Kmart should provide valuable lessons (though Burkle insists he hedged his shares).

name: Billionaires
bio: Former metals trader survivied the gangster wars in the aluminum industry, then in 2000, at age 31, assumed control of Russian Aluminum, the country’s dominant producer. His holding company, Basic Element, now controls Russian Aluminum (together with Roman Abramovich’s Millhouse Capital), automobile manufacturer GAZ, aircraft manufacturer Aviacor, other interests. Currently attempting a highly contested takeover of one of Russia’s largest pulp and paper manufacturers. Married to the daughter of former President Yeltsin&#39s chief of staff, who in turn married Yeltsin&#39s daughter—which means that Deripaska is now Yeltsin&#39s grandson by marriage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Famous for billion-dollar bet against the British pound in 1992 that generated 30% returns for George SorosO Quantum Fund. Parted with Soros in 2000, still manages $4 billion in his Duquesne Capital hedge fund, returned $1.5 billion in annual gains to investors last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical doctor served as Air Force surgeon before founding Hospital Corp. of America with father in 1968. Merged with Columbia Healthcare in 1994; now nation's largest hospital owner. Pulled out of semiretirement to handle lengthy Medicare-fraud investigation 1997. Stepped down again this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Buyout specialist runs Platinum Equity, 21 operating companies with $4 billion in revenues. Emigrated with family from Israel 1968; worked with brother Alec (see) until 1995 split. Brothers now neighbors in LA, compete for deals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billion-dollar beneficiary of Citigroup’s 2001 buyout of Banamex, Harp now spends much of his time tending to his nation’s poor. Through Banamex Social Foundation he oversees development aid to the impoverished of south Mexican state of Oaxaca. He also remains the chairman of Banamex’s holding company and sits on the board of Citigroup.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third son of coffee magnate Max Herz and wife Ingeburg. Apparent ringleader in the very public family row, which eventually led to the unseating of older brother Günter from his almost 35 years as head of the family-held Tchibo Holding. Michael and brothers Joachim and Wolfgang, who all sit on Tchibo’s supervisory board, have sided against Günter and their sister, Daniela. Günter reportedly was pressing for an IPO against the wishes of the family, but the fight has deeper roots: At their father’s death Günter took control of the firm, eventually pushing his brothers out of management. Now they’ve pushed him out. Personally has a 18% stake in the family holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth son of coffee magnate Max Herz and wife Ingeburg. Sits on the supervisory board of Tchibo Holding, one of Germany’s largest companies, along with brothers Michael and Joachim. Has sided with his two brothers against older brother Günter in their very public row regarding the management of their family wealth. Has an 18% stake in the family fortune, which consists of 100% of Tchibo Holding, 27.6% of Nivea-producer Beiersdorf and the $4 billion proceeds from the sale of Reemtsma cigarettes to Imperial Tobacco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Promise, now Japan’s third-largest consumer finance company, in 1962. Remains honorary chairman of the group, which is fighting the industry slump by lowering costs and expanding into other parts of Asia. It is using a venture in Taiwan as its first beachhead into the still undeveloped consumer finance market in the region. Third son of a farmer, owns 600 hectares of farm in Hokkaido.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs mutual fund giant Franklin Resources with half-brother Rupert Johnson (see). Yale grad and ex-Army lieutenant, Charles is chairman and CEO. After last year's purchase of Fiduciary Trust, firm now manages $271 billion in assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: It took Daryl Katz (pronounced cates) just a decade to cobble together 1,800 pharmacies and create the seventh-largest pharmacy chain in the Western Hemisphere. The pharmacist’s son owns 100% of the Edmonton-based Katz Group, now one of Canada’s largest private companies. Katz is a contradictory character. He doesn&#39t seek the limelight, but is a tough dealmaker who bullies those who get in his way. His formula: Buy up distressed pharmacy chains at bargain-basement prices with the help of drug distributor McKesson, then hire capable execs to turn the chains around. His latest rescue effort is Youngstown, Ohio-based Drug Emporium.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third-generation business best known for plumbing fixtures, started as steel foundry in 1873 by John Michael Kohler. Now in furniture, cabinetry, tile, engines, generators, golf resorts. With sister Ruth, controls $2.6 billion (sales) firm after buying out 300 shareholders in 1998.

name: Billionaires
bio: Spiraling telecom and communications stocks have Malone on the prowl. Deal to buy Deutsche Telekom collapsed in February under regulatory pressure, but Malone still looking to expand in Europe. Through holding company Liberty Media, already owns large stakes in AOL, News Corp., many other media companies. Built cable giant TCI along with Bob Magness (d. 1996), sold to AT&T in 1999 for $54 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads the Hong Leong Group in Malaysia, with interests in banking, financial services, manufacturing and real estate development. His Guoco Group sold Dao Heng Bank in 2001 for $5.4 billion, more than three times book value. It was one of the highest prices ever paid for an Asian bank. Some saw sale as yet another testimony to Quek’s skill as a businessman. This banker also has a Barrister-at-Law from Middle Temple in the United Kingdom.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-owner, with James Goodnight, of the world’s largest privately held software company, SAS Institute, ended long flirtation with public offering in wake of recent tech slump. SAS now mining new talent from unemployed techies looking for safer job environment. Despite the duo&#39s best efforts to keep it aloft, side project Midway Airlines grounded for now: carrier bankrupt even after $52 million injection by Sall and Goodnight. Partners met at North Carolina State, started SAS 26 years ago after developing statistical analysis program. Sales now top $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Still the youngest billionaire: inherited one of the world’s oldest fortunes on his 18th birthday, in June 2001. For more than 300 years his family held the monopoly over imperial communications between Vienna and the Hapsburg empire. Today the fortune includes extensive landholdings, real estate, castles, works of art and businesses. When not in school, the young and eligible prince lives with his mother and two sisters in a castle that is reputed to be larger than Buckingham Palace.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former plastics engineer, his business career took off when his close friend Yuri Luzhkov became mayor of Moscow in 1992. Transformed his municipal Committee for Science and Technology into a commercial enterprise, gained access to lucrative government contracts, real estate and capital. His empire, AFK Sistema (“The System”), now consists of some 200 companies with holdings ranging from microchips to toy stores. Most valuable holding is 40% stake in Russia’s largest cellular company. Denies that his company was started with municipal government financial aid; insists he accumulated his first capital exporting oil, importing electronics and food products in the early 1990s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Snagged one of three coveted gaming licenses to operate casinos in Macau. Irascible personality might be essential to navigate island's corruption and extortionists; 1,000-room addition to the Venetian in Las Vegas hotel will make it one of world's largest. Boston cab driver's son made first fortune in trade shows, sold Comdex in 1995 for $860 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: NYC cabbie borrowed $3,000 at age 31 to trade commodities. Started Caxton hedge fund in 1983. Today manages $9 billion in assets. Fund closed to new investors, but those lucky enough to get in earned 30% last year. American Enterprise Institute vice chairman invested in conservative daily New York Sun, where daughter Rachel now works as a reporter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former car salesman found fortune after placing a $3 classified ad in Chicago Tribune to sell his computer. Began CDW in 1982: direct seller of computer products, services to business and government. Sales: $4 billion. Stepped down as chief executive last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband and wife. Ann's father Bud Walton (d. 1995) went in with his brother Sam on Wal-Mart. His stake now divided between Ann and sister Nancy Laurie. Stan: real estate developer, including many shopping centers anchored around Wal-Marts, also 560,000 acres of ranch land. Stan owns stake in NFL's St. Louis Rams, all of NBA's Denver Nuggets and Colorado Avalanche. Rams made it to 2002 Super Bowl but lost to New England, Avs knocked out of Stanley Cup playoffs at conference championship, Nuggets still routinely miss playoffs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of Campbell Soup genius Dr. John T. Dorrance, innovator who developed soup condensation process, purchased company from uncle 1914. Left half fortune to son John Jr., remainder to 3 daughters. John died 1989, children inherited his stake.  Family still holds approximately half of outstanding shares. Mary Alice: horse breeder.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Home Depot with Arthur Blank after pair was dismissed from a now-defunct home improvement chain. Active philanthropist in Atlanta.

name: Billionaires
bio: The fortune draws from almost every sector of the Chilean economy, from banks to real estate to the management of shipping ports. The main holding is pulp manufacturer CMPC, which saw profits fall more than 50% last year as a result of damp pulp prices and the crisis in Argentina, which is an important market for them. But Matte isn’t panicking: “We’re calm because ... we turn out products that are basic necessities. We assume people will continue using toilet paper,” Matte reportedly said.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wildcatter sold Mitchell Energy & Development to Devon Energy last year for $3.5 billion. Now DevonOs largest individual shareholder, with 9% stake. Renovating hometown of Galveston, Tex. Former Amoco employee went solo in 1946, struck it rich in northern Texas gas fields.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout made fortune building homes after WWII, lost most of it in real estate crash of 1964. Rebuilt fortune with California real estate, large stake in Dole Foods. Took conglomerate Castle & Cooke private in 2000, added dozens of properties, including Hawaiian island of Lanai. Extensive private holdings range from quarries to nationOs largest auto chassis maker.

name: Billionaires
bio: The youngest granddaughter of company founder Mario Prada runs the $1.6 billion (sales) family-owned luxury-goods maker with husband Patrizio Bertelli. Postponed widely anticipated public offering for a third time last year, but says she is in no rush. As for the clothes, Miuccia says she likes sexy, not “obvious sexy.” Bought an additional 25% of chic line Jil Sander. Husband is an avid sailor.
title: Owner, Fashion Designer

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of electronics retail giant stepped down as CEO, leaving company nation's biggest consumer electronics chain with nearly 500 stores and leading music retailer thanks to 2000 purchase of Musicland, operator of Suncoast and Sam Goody. Started in 1966 with Sound of Music store in St. Paul, changed name 1983, went public 1985. Now enraging rivals with strategy of marketing links to top musicians including U2, Limp Bizkit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned an obscure Kyoto playing card company into one of the world’s best-known game companies, Nintendo. The 75-year-old stepped down as chief executive after 53 years, in May 2002. The company is in mixed shape. The Game Boy Advance handheld player continues to dominate that sector, yet the GameCube player, Nintendo’s response to the Sony PlayStation, has not taken off. Yamauchi has set up a venture fund to back future generations of inexpensive videogame software.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Russia’s largest oil company, Lukoil. As acting minister of fuel and energy in the last Soviet government in 1991, cobbled together oil giant Lukoil out of some of the best Russian oil properties, then muscled in on the biggest deals in the Caspian Sea basin, bought refineries in Eastern Europe and the Getty gas station chain in the U.S. Lately Lukoil has stagnated, underperforming its Russian rivals by almost all measures; over the past year, Alekperov has endured the mysterious kidnapping of his chief financial officer, a messy political struggle with the governor of the oil-rich Nenets region and Saddam Hussein tearing up the long-standing contract for Lukoil to develop one of Iraq’s biggest oilfields.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bouygues Telecom is a rare bright spot in Europe’s tattered telephony market, pulling in healthy profits while crosstown rival France Télécom staggers under a massive debt load. Call it acting on a hunch: Bouygues avoided indulging in the acquisition and license-fee bingeing of the bubble years. He wisely passed when the French government offered him 3G licenses for $5 billion in 2000. Last year Bouygues pocketed one for $600 million. Also owns an international construction company that recently erected barriers in the port of Monaco to protect it from erosion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Chinese immigrants, he  turned the family’s modest animal feed operation into a sprawling conglomerate. His $13 billion (revenues) Charoen Pokphand (the CP Group), which he refers to as the “kitchen to the world,” is the world’s largest exporter of black tiger shrimp and derives more than two-thirds of its revenues from agri-business; also has interests in telecom, convenience stores and motorcycles. A longtime investor in mainland China, he cut the ribbon to his Super Brand Mall in October 2002. Enjoys breeding native chickens from Thailand in his spare time.

name: Billionaires
bio: A secretive and committed Buddhist, Chen delisted his flagship company Nan Fung Textiles back in 1989. Riding the real estate boom of the 1990s, Chen seemed to have fared well despite the economic downturn. He bought some 12% of fellow billionaire Ng Teng Fong’s Sinoland and has of late been building up its portfolio of luxury properties.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded in 1969 with a single drugstore, the Jean Coutu Group now includes more than 600 outlets in Canada and North America. The former pharmacist knows the value of a good photo opportunity--he sometimes works behind the counter in the chains’ largest store in Quebec. In  September, he named his 47-year-old son Francois, Jean Coutu&#39s president, to succeed as chief executive.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dot-com duo of Cuban and Todd Wagner sold Internet broadcasting outfit Broadcast.com to Yahoo for $5.7 billion in stock. Shrewdly placed put and call “collars” to lock up fortune before Internet bust. Volatile Cuban used part of windfall to buy pro basketball’s Dallas Mavericks; fined record $1.5 million over two seasons, mostly for verbally abusing game officials. Maybe Cuban, once a high-profile bachelor, will find his upcoming marriage a soothing influence. With Wagner, going Hollywood: financed documentary Searching for Debra Winger; bought Rysher TV and film library (Sex and the City, Nash Bridges).

name: Billionaires
bio: Charismatic Cornell graduate cofounded enterprise-management software developer PeopleSoft 1987 with $2 million. Profits grew quickly, took public 1992. Sales: $2 billion. Relinquished chief executive title in 1999; now focuses on animal welfare.

name: Billionaires
bio: Savvy sister. Sold her share of the family firm, Fomentos de Construcciones y Contratas, to her older sister Esther for $800 million in 1997. Has since carefully invested the proceeds in companies like Banco de Bilbao y Vizcaya, Endesa, Acerinox, Nestlé, Repsol and Telefónica. Her move has paid off handsomely: she is now wealthier than her sister.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left Bear Stearns with first cousin George Roberts and colleague Jerome Kohlberg (see) to form investment boutique KKR. Bought underperforming companies using high-yield bonds. Immortalized as Obarbarians at the gatesO during Nabisco buyout of 1989. Kohlberg left 1987; partners still run firm using less debt in longer-term deals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Early Enron holder still able to smile after selling Cogen Technologies to the disgraced energy giant in 1998 for $1.5 billion in cash and stock, the bulk of which he sold before the flameout. Now focused on sports. Landed NFL expansion team Houston Texans for $700 million, struck record $300 million stadium naming-rights deal with Reliant Energy. Horseman still owns piece of two energy plants.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Steven (see), ditched father’s real estate business 1979, consolidated manufacturing ventures under name of favourite Montana fishing tributary Danaher 3 years later. Acquired and revamped underperforming assets, now leading manufacturer of tools, components, and process-environmental controls. Recent acquisitions include Gilbarco and Videojet.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Mitchell (see), ditched father’s real estate business 1979, consolidated manufacturing ventures under name of favourite Montana fishing tributary Danaher 3 years later. Acquired and revamped underperforming assets, now leading manufacturer of tools, components, and process-environmental controls. Recent acquisitions include Gilbarco and Videojet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left Bear Stearns with first cousin Henry Kravis and Jerome Kohlberg (see) to form investment boutique KKR. Bought underperforming companies using high-yield bonds. Immortalized as "barbarians at the gates" during Nabisco buyout of 1989. Kohlberg left 1987; partners still run firm using less debt in longer-term deals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aggressive dealmaker who succeeded his father to head Singapore’s United Overseas Bank in 1974. Proceeded to transform the bank, which was founded in 1935 by his father and six other Chinese businessmen, through a series of mergers and takeovers. Under his watch, United Overseas Bank has become the largest bank in Singapore, with more than $60 billion in assets. An ambitious and talented banker, Wee wants to turn UOB into a “regional financial powerhouse.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Bass family took flak last year for selling Disney shares to meet margin call. With stock dipping below $15, Lee and his brothers Sid and Edward save a little face. Still smarting after late-1990s bets in technology (Globalstar), biotech (Human Genome Sciences), but stake in Hawthorn Financial returned 1,300% in past year. Father, Perry, built investment empire on oil fortune inherited from uncle Sid Richardson (d. 1951). Handed business to eldest son, Sid, in 1968, prompting brother Robert (see) to break out on his own. Other brothers parted ways with longtime money manager Tommy Taylor in 1999, after ill-timed Canadian investments. Bass family still holds large Disney stake; major force in reviving downtown Fort Worth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Since he sold his Banco Bozano, Simonsen to Spain’s Banco Santander Central Hispano in 2000, Bozano has dropped out of the business headlines in Brazil. Talk is that he married his race horses’ veterinarian, sired a daughter with her and lives in Greenwich, Connecticut, though he keeps a pied-à-terre in Rio.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Mediolanum SpA, a life insurance and fund management company he cofounded. Mediolanum is part of  Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s business empire. Doris is entertaining the possibility of buying out Berlusconi’s stake. In his spare time, he enjoys mountain biking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Campbell Soup founder John T. Dorrance; left half of fortune to son, John Jr., remainder to 3 daughters. John Jr. died 1989, children inherited his stake (eldest son, John III, became Irish citizen to avoid U.S. taxes). Family members still control half of Campbell Soup Co. stock. Bennett Dorrance avid gardener, recently pledged $5 million to Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tumbling stocks hit Foriel-Destezet’s fortune hard last year, with his principal holdings falling in value by more than a third. London-based to escape French wealth taxes, Foriel-Destezet has reconfigured his investment portfolio to avoid French companies. The bulk of his wealth is derived from his 18% stake in Adecco, the temporary-services company he cofounded with Swiss billionaire Klaus Jacobs. He also has investments in ISS, a Danish office cleaning firm, and Securitas, a Swedish security company. Last spring Foriel-Destezet resigned from the board of Vivendi Universal, one of a string of board resignations that undermined support for then-chief executive Jean-Marie Messier.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of tireless salesman Curtis Carlson (d. 1999), who invested $50 to start Gold Bond Trading Stamps in 1938, built into marketing, travel, hospitality conglomerate that includes Radisson Hotels, T.G.I. Friday's. Sister Marilyn placed in charge of company in 1998. Sizable Carlson Companies travel segment struggling along with rest of industry after September terrorist attacks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started payroll outsourcing business with $3,000 in 1971. Took Paychex public 1983. Now processes paychecks for more than 350,000 customers. Spent $20 million on failed bids for New York's governor's office in 1994, 1998. Reportedly spent $75 million this year on a third campaign.

name: Billionaires
bio: Personal injury lawyer made fortune in  Texaco-Pennzoil case 1987; received estimated $345 million in fees. Now defending one of Enron's law firms, Vinson & Elkins: "I don't need the money, but I'll take it."

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs mutual fund giant Franklin Resources with half-brother Charles Johnson (see). Rupert, Washington and Lee grad and ex-Marine, is vice chairman. After last year's purchase of Fiduciary Trust, firm now manages $271 billion in assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Enron president wisely left firm in 1996, uncomfortable with "asset light" strategy. Bought Enron's asset-rich liquid-gas pipeline operations with college classmate William Morgan. Today Kinder Morgan controls over 30,000 miles of pipe, transports 2 million barrels a day. Also owns bulk terminals, power plants. Vietnam vet careful to avoid Enron excesses: flies coach class, pays himself just $1 a year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad sold patent on soft contact lens for $60 million in 1971. Started Vision Cable, sold for $220 million 1982. Later formed Metro Mobile cell service, sold to Bell Atlantic for $2.6 billion in 1992. Current chief of natural gas company Southern Union also owns 19 Spanish-language radio stations. Tools around on Adela, his 185-foot, two-masted schooner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Boss of Severstal, Russia’s largest steel company. Son of millworker parents, in the mid-1980s Mordashov left to study economics in Leningrad, then returned and was named finance director of the local steel mill. When the plant’s elderly general director instructed him to buy up the shares of the company so it would not fall into the hands of an outsider, Mordashov bought most of the shares himself. Became general director of the company and built it into a conglomerate, acquiring automaker UAZ, coal companies, railroad companies, port facilities, local TV stations and newspapers. Having been targeted by President Bush’s imposition of steel tariffs in last year, Mordashov is a leading proponent of Russia’s entry into the WTO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile partner of Warren Buffett serves as vice chairman of Berkshire Hathaway. Met Buffett 1959, started investing in Berkshire soon after. Runs Berkshire's Wesco Financial subsidiary out of Los Angeles; also guides legal publisher Daily Journal Corp., sits on board of big-box retailer Costco. Harvard-trained lawyer avid fisherman, supporter of arts in southern California: donated 100 Berkshire shares to help build new wing at Pasadena's Huntington Library.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of tireless salesman Curtis Carlson (d. 1999) who invested $50 to start Gold Bond Trading Stamps in 1938, built into marketing, travel, hospitality conglomerate that includes Radisson Hotels, T.G.I. Friday's. Marilyn placed in charge of company in 1998, sister Barbara Carlson Gage retains significant stake in firm. Sizable Carlson Companies travel segment struggling along with rest of industry after September terrorist attacks.

name: Billionaires
bio: The cheese whiz. Chairman and CEO of Quebec-based Saputo Inc., Canada’s largest dairy processor, joins the billionaires club this year. Fiscal year March 2002 profits rose 29% to $106 million, while sales hit $2.3 billion, up 60% from 2001. Company close to reaching a sponsorship deal with Rocketsports Racing. The son of a cheesemaker, Saputo helped his Italian family start a mom-and-pop dairy company shortly after moving to Canada in 1952. Became big cheese himself, chairman of the board and president since 1969.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with sister Charmaine, owns almost half of his family’s financial services company, Schroders Plc. Watched his net worth tumble $1 billion thanks to Schroders’ ailing stock price, off 45% since last year. Nonetheless the company presses on with expansion into alternative investments. In October 2001, Schroder paid $48 million for London-based Beaumont Capital Management, a hedge fund with $275 million under management. Schroder is known as an amiable man who loves flying airplanes, hunting stags and relaxing at his Scottish estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gained fame and fortune in 1980s as top salesman for Oracle. Developed internal sales automation software; left 1990 after Oracle Chief Larry Ellison (see) scrapped his plans to bring it to market. Launched Siebel Systems 1993; IPO 1996. Sales doubled 5 of 6 years, but hit wall in 2001: software licensing revenues off 33% in the first 6 months of last year, shares down 77% from their year high in January. Politically active, hopes to juice sales in public sector. New $2.1 million PAC, largest in tech industry, should help.

name: Billionaires
bio: Palo Alto residential broker in 1960s branched into commercial projects in Silicon Valley. Today owns 11 million square feet, 470 acres, 5,800 apartment units. With son, John Michael, launched $10 million Sobrato Affordable Housing Fund. Sold 400,000-square-foot office space to VeriSign last October for $283 million, spent proceeds on apartment units throughout western states.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded for-profit University of Phoenix for working adults in 1973, took public in 1994. Now schools 148,100 students at 63 campuses, 109 learning centers. John: former union organizer, San Jose State humanities professor; supports genetic cloning, antiaging research, legalization of marijuana. His son, Peter, serves as vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Peter's father, John, founded for-profit University of Phoenix for working adults in 1973, took public in 1994. Now schools 148,100 students at 63 campuses, 109 learning centers. Peter serves as vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed. Received Army contract during WWII, but lost it at war’s end. Marketed beds to civilians, added new products like cast cutters, specialty stretchers. After Homer’s son Lee died in 1976, siblings brought in John Brown (see) to run $2.6 billion sales Stryker Corp. Jon, an architect, splits time between Kalamazoo and Palm Beach.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed. Received Army contract during WWII, but lost it at war’s end. Marketed beds to civilians, added new products like cast cutters, specialty stretchers. After Homer’s son Lee died in 1976, siblings brought in John Brown (see) to run $2.6 billion sales Stryker Corp. Eldest sister, Ronda, sits on Stryker board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Asia’s mall king. His SM Prime boasts eleven "supermalls" on 1.7 million square meters of floor space. Last year, he offered shares in his Banco de Oro Universal and luxury resorts developer Highlands Prime on the Philippine Stock Exchange. Cooks in his spare time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of William Ziff Jr., who built Ziff-Davis Publishing empire (PC, Car & Driver, Boating). Dad sold company for $2.1 billion 1994, retired to Florida. Brothers invest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments. Strategy: hire money managers like Edward Lampert, Daniel Och to run various funds, invest in corporate debt, tech stocks, private companies, including DreamWorks SKG.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of William Ziff Jr., who built Ziff-Davis Publishing empire (PC, Car & Driver, Boating). Dad sold company for $2.1 billion 1994, retired to Florida. Brothers invest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments. Strategy: hire money managers like Edward Lampert, Daniel Och to run various funds, invest in corporate debt, tech stocks, private companies, including DreamWorks SKG.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of William Ziff Jr., who built Ziff-Davis Publishing empire (PC, Car & Driver, Boating). Dad sold company for $2.1 billion 1994, retired to Florida. Brothers invest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments. Strategy: hire money managers like Edward Lampert, Daniel Och to run various funds, invest in corporate debt, tech stocks, private companies, including DreamWorks SKG.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Richard Peery (see), bought California farmland in 1960s using little leverage; converted into pricey office space. Duo became two of Silicon Valley's biggest commercial landlords with more than 12 million square feet. Lately feeling tech industry's pain: vacancy rates now approaching 15%.

name: Billionaires
bio: His 18.8% share of Metro Ag, one of the world’s largest retail groups, is worth a bit less this year, because of Germany’s miserable retail climate. Currently developing property in central Berlin, with plans for luxury hotels, apartments, shops and offices. He is reportedly a close friend of beleaguered former billionaire Leo Kirch.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker, Botin has emerged as the unchallenged boss of Banco Santander Central Hispano, Spain’s biggest bank in terms of assets ($373 million). With an estimated 10% share of the Latin American market, BSCH has not been impervious to that region&#39s current economic problems. The bank missed its latest profit estimates and is now focusing on controlling costs and unloading nonperforming holdings. Daughter Ana Patricia is considered to be his likely successor. Botin&#39s great-grandfather discovered the famous Altamira caves in northern Spain in 1879.

name: Billionaires
bio: A trained orthopedist and theologian, he gave up his medical practice in 1956 to run the shoe business started by his father in 1913. Today Deichmann-Schuhe GmbH is Europe’s largest shoe retailer, with over 1,800 stores and 2001 sales of $2.3 billion. Last year the group sold 90 million pairs of shoes. In the U.S. it owns Rack Room Shoes, with 349 stores in 23 states. Deichmann runs the company as joint CEO with his eldest son, Heinrich Otto. A practicing Lutheran, he is an active, hands-on philanthropist, donating time and money to various missionary and humanitarian organizations at home and abroad—in India, in particular, where he supports a program for leprosy victims, which he visits yearly.

name: Billionaires
bio: The MIT graduate heads a privately owned third-generation family conglomerate whose businesses range from locks and office furniture to soaps and software services. The family&#39s biggest asset is a 3,500-acre estate in suburban Mumbai, where Godrej is building a $5 million hospital. His U.S.-educated daughters, Tanya and Nisa, also work with him. A keen sportsman, Godrej is a major donor to the elite Indian School of Business, affiliated with the Wharton School and Northwestern’s Kellogg.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Kit" scooped up a spicy $1.1 billion windfall when he sold salsa slinger Pace Foods to Campbell Soup in 1995. Since then his Silver Ventures has invested in the House of Blues club chain, salsamaker Van de Walle Foods. Big backer of Christus Santa Rosa Children's Hospital Center in San Antonio.

name: Billionaires
bio: At 35, Harmsworth might still be the youngest person on the board of the Daily Mail & General Trust, one of the U.K.’s largest media empires. But Viscount Rothermere has proven his mettle in the four years since his father’s death, when he succeeded as chairman of DMGT. Even in this abysmal advertising climate, DMGT’s profits are up, as is circulation for its flagship paper, the Daily Mail. Rothermere is looking into further expansion of DMGT’s successful re-entry into the Irish newspaper market.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mathematician Hector is one of the founders of German software giant SAP. Fell out with his partners in 1997. Since then devotes his time to managing the H.W.& J. Hector Stiftung, his cultural and philanthropic foundation established to support cancer and AIDS research, as well as art and historical preservation. He is a strong supporter of the University of Karlsruhe, which has established a chair in his name.

name: Billionaires
bio: His $300 million Snowbasin ski resort opened for this year's Winter Olympics. Even with the Games gone, Holding's 377-room, Grand America downtown Salt Lake City hotel still booked. Stays busy with other assets, including convenience stores, gas stations, Sinclair Oil, skiing mecca Sun Valley Resort in Idaho.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of ultra-stylish sunglasses-and-accessory maker Oakley. Started with motorcycle goggles in 1975, started sunglasses in 1984. Avoided advertising, but got free publicity from athletes wearing Oakley shades. Now also makes watches, shoes, apparel. Publicity-shy Jannard tried to withdraw from day-to-day management in mid-1990s, but came back as CEO in 1999 after stock dived; stock tripled after his return. Stock nose-dived again last fall after tiff with largest distributor, Sunglass Hut; rebounded after dispute resolved in December, but fourth-quarter profit still off 66%.

name: Billionaires
bio: With John Herma and Jay Baker took over Kohl’s department store chain in 1986 management buyout. Kellogg rose from store manager to CEO, oversaw expansion of family outfit into national chain with 420 branches in 32 states. Sales: $8 billion. Retired 1999 but still a major holder.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 29% of Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas, the company her father founded in 1944. She is also one of the most influential women in Spain today as  member of the board of the $5.4 billion (revenues) construction group, which has built most of Spain’s bridges and highways.  Made news last year when 20 of her paintings and sculptures by artists such as Goya and Pissarro were stolen from her Madrid apartment in one of Spain’s biggest art thefts. Police recovered all but three.

name: Billionaires
bio: Majority shareholder (55.8%) and president of publicly traded Kühne & Nagel, one of the world’s leading transport and logistics groups. His grandfather founded the company in 1890. Kuhne moved himself and company to tax-friendly Switzerland in 1975. Married with no children, Kuhne, 65, will be last family member to run the firm.

name: Billionaires
bio: British-born, Bahama-based billionaire Joseph Lewis enjoys a very private life. Through his conglomerate, Tavistock Group, Lewis invests in an array of businesses, like sports teams, food companies and financial services outfits. He himself runs Tavistock’s currency trading arm, its largest division. Daughter Vivienne Silverton runs the family’s Isleworth Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father started insurance firm in 1937; Peter took over 1965, accelerated growth by insuring high-risk drivers. Today Progressive Corp. is nation's fourth-largest auto insurer. Art fanatic gave $50 million to Guggenheim Museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Red" dropped out of law school to sell cars. Owned first dealership at 25, expanded to 50, now down to 8. Fortune tied up in Clear Channel Communications, radio outfit started in 1972 with Lowry Mays (see). Now focuses with daughter Marsha on Minnesota Vikings, which he is shopping around.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bear market clawing at world's largest networking manufacturer. Questions about accounting, acquisitions don't help. Former Honeywell exec became Cisco chief in 1988, took public in 1990, stepped aside for John Chambers in 1995. Remains chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Henry Samueli co-founded Broadcom in 1991, maker of high-speed chips for communications devices, cable modems. Weakening demand for chips knocked shares down 59% since January high. Nicholas and Samueli are big backers of Orange County Performing Arts Center despite lawsuit filed against Broadcom by four of the Center’s board members.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Arrillaga (see), bought California farmland in 1960s using little leverage; converted into pricey office space, became two of Silicon Valley's biggest commercial landlords with more than 12 million square feet. Lately feeling tech industry's pain: vacancy rates now approaching 15%.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Henry Nicholas co-founded Broadcom in 1991, maker of high-speed chips for communications devices, cable modems. Weakening demand for chips knocked shares down 59% since January high. Nicholas and Samueli are big backers of Orange County Performing Arts Center despite lawsuit filed against Broadcom by four of the Center’s board members.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Sibneft, Russia’s fifth-largest oil company. Schvidler trained as an oil engineer in Moscow, received an MBA from New York’s Fordham University, then worked for Deloitte & Touche. His career took off when he teamed up with Roman Abramovich and established Runicom SA, a Switzerland-based oil trading firm. In 1995 the men partnered with Boris Berezovsky to gain control of oil giant Sibneft.  Schvidler has been president of since 1998; together with Abramovich and some other partners, he has pooled his oil, aluminum, timber and industrial assets in a British-based holding company called Millhouse Capital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tour of Vietnam as Marine. After war, followed up on Yale economics thesis: speedy postal delivery via efficient air freight service. Today FedEx's 647 aircraft deliver 5 million packages daily. Transportation in blood: grandfather was riverboat captain, father helped found Greyhound bus lines. Also dabbles in Hollywood, backs production house Alcon Entertainment (My Dog Skip, Insomnia).

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year was a major turning point in this colorful man’s roller coaster of a career. Briefly worth $76 billion in 2000,  Son saw his net worth fall below $1 billion last year, only to rebound. Rumors of imminent bankruptcy swirled.  Son is betting on a new broadband business in Japan to lift his fortunes again.

name: Billionaires
bio: A widow to reckon with. Won a power struggle with Leo Kirch for control of one of Germany’s leading publishing groups, Axel Springer Verlag. Owns 55% of the publisher of conservative daily Die Welt and tabloid Bild Zeitung. Now being sued by her husband’s grandson, Axel Sven Springer, who is challenging the inheritance agreement in an effort to get a bigger stake in the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed. Received Army contract during WWII, but lost it at war’s end. Marketed beds to civilians, added new products like cast cutters, specialty stretchers. After Homer’s son Lee died in 1976, siblings brought in John Brown (see) to run $2.6 billion sales Stryker Corp. Patricia lives in Colorado, supports local charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: The chairman of Stage Holding, a $450 million musical theater company with brands like Holiday on Ice, owes his fortune to television production. In 1998 he bought the live entertainment division of Endemol, the Dutch television production company he led with fellow billionaire John de Mol. Two years later Telefonica bought Endemol for $5.3 billion in stock. Van den Ende is credited with pioneering the format that is now the basis of reality shows like Fear Factor, a popular NBC series.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thailand’s beverage billionaire. Produced and sold drinks with names like Krating Daeng in Thailand for years before he met Dietrich Mateschitz (see). The two teamed up for the worldwide marketing of the Red Bull Energy Drink in the late 1980s. The caffeinated beverage is now drunk in 70 countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Even real estate not immune from Enron fallout: Arthur Andersen pulled out of deal to be anchor tenant of Times Square Tower being built. Owns 10% of REIT Boston Properties, which he cofounded in 1970: Boston's Prudential Center, San Francisco's Embarcadero Center, Manhattan's Citigroup Center. Now buying Citigroup headquarters in New York for $1.06 billion. Late-blooming publisher catching flak for struggling U.S. News & World Report and New York's Daily News, but sold Fast Company at height of market for $365 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: The visionary Bellon turned a small Marseilles catering outfit into the world&#39s biggest catering company, Sodexho Alliance. Last year Sodexho secured an enormous catering contract, an eight-year $880 million deal with the U.S. Marines. Nevertheless, the company’s stock tanked this year, largely because of fears that the global recession will mean smaller outlays for catering. Corporate mismanagement of British operations didn’t help either. The company has also suffered negative p.r. and boycott threats because of its global prison-catering business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former loan processor, mortgage broker in Silicon Valley took warrants, stock in lieu of rent from fledgling tech companies. Suffering slightly from real estate slump, but Mission West Properties still manages 100 properties totaling 7 million square feet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gained control of Surgutneftegaz, Russia’s fourth-largest oil company, during the privatization auctions of 1994 and 1995. Is known in Russia as a competent and honest industrial tycoon; many regard Surgutneftegaz to be the best-managed oil company in Russia, though outside investors have been grumbling at the company’s paltry dividends, primitive accounting and underutilized cash horde. Exceptionally private: dubbed the “Hermit of Siberia,” Bogdanov rarely leaves his remote oil town, never grants interviews and shuns the trappings of wealth; often walks to work and does his own grocery shopping.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turkey’s youngest billionaire transformed a small auto parts business into Park Group, a $1 billion (sales) diversified empire with interests in media, textiles, energy and mining. Expanded his media holdings last year by purchasing a popular television network, newspapers, magazines and a distribution company for good measure. Also owns enormous soda ash reserve, used for making glass. Should U.S. rivals withdraw from Middle East, Ciner’s reserves could become gold mines. In the works: an olive oil processing plant in Syria. Charity begins at home for Ciner. Last year he built three schools in Turkey and donated them to the government.

name: Billionaires
bio: After wife complained of writing checks for bills, developed Quicken personal finance software with Stanford programmer Tom Proulx 1983. Took public 10 years later. Intuit software now used by 25 million people. Could have been more: feds nixed Microsoft's $1.5 billion bid for the company in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: An original partner of Endemol, a television production outfit behind big reality show hits like Big Brother and Fear Factor. Spanish telecom giant Telefonica bought Endemol three years ago in a deal valued at $5.3 billion. Today De Mol is chief creative officer, actively involved in scouting and producing show ideas. His company continues to perform well. In 2001, the most recent year financial results of the company were released, Endemol posted profits of $163 million on $987 million in revenue, up 51% and 63% respectively.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Red" learned lumber business from father, who built makeshift sawmills in family's backyard in 1930s. Father went bust, set out for California; Red followed later. In 1950 started lumber outfit. Took Sierra Pacific Industries public 1969; bought back five years later. Today California's largest private landowner. Spars with environmentalists over logging, even after selling 731 acres of land to preservationists.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family’s scrap metal business into a cascade of assets in media, utilities and oil, much of it through holding companies Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille and Geneva-listed Pargesa Holding. Key investments include a shared 25% stake in German media behemoth Bertelsmann. Known as a workaholic who claims he’ll never retire, Baron Frere clearly kicks back now and again. He is a connoisseur of fine wine and co-owner with French billionaire Bernard Arnault of the Château Cheval Blanc vineyard.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norway’s only billionaire. He and his father opened their first discount supermarket together in the late 1970s. Three years ago  the group entered a joint venture with supermarket giant Royal Ahold. Hagen got a cash payout and a 20% stake. These days he is buying up shares in Orkla, part-owner of brewer Carlsberg, and in Steen & Strom, which owns   shopping centers in Norway, Sweden and Denmark. Reportedly owns one of the biggest sailboats in Europe and his own island in the Caribbean.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of six grandchildren of William Randolph Hearst (d. 1951), notorious media magnate who built nation's largest newspaper chain. Today Hearst Corp. operates 12 dailies (including flagship San Francisco Chronicle), 16 magazines (HarperOs Bazaar, Cosmopolitan), TV stations via publicly traded Hearst-Argyle (of which Hearst holds 66%). Also partners with Disney (cable channel ESPN), Dow Jones (Smart Money magazine), Oprah Winfrey (O magazine).

name: Billionaires
bio: An original investor in $1.6 billion (sales) Amdocs Ltd., a customer relationship management and billing software firm for large telecom outfits. (One out of every two phone calls made in North America relies on Amdocs software.)  Since Amdocs went public on the New York stock exchange in 1998, Kahn has cashed out an estimated $800 million worth of shares. He’s also a part-owner of Aurec Group, an Israeli-based private equity firm with cable and telecom investments. The press-shy former diver founded Coral World International, a string of aquariums in Eilat, Maui and Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of venerable Hong Kong business leader Li Ka-shing. Borrowed money from his father to open Star TV, which he then sold for about $900 million. Parlayed some of that into an ambitious attempt to make his Hong Kong PCCW, now listed, the world’s largest broadband Internet business. As part of that bid, bought fixed-line operator Cable & Wireless HKT in 2000 for a whopping $28 billion. Plans derailed when tech bubble imploded. The Cable & Wireless HKT purchase saddled the group with a heavy debt load, which Li has been working diligently to reduce. Still, investors shy away from his stock; once had a market capitalization as high as $77 billion, his company’s market cap is now just $3.3. Richard is a licensed jet plane pilot and avid scuba diver.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of John Willard Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started with a Washington, D.C. root beer stand in 1927 and opened first Marriott hotel in 1957. Now more than 2,000 properties worldwide. Harvard M.B.A. Richard is chairman of Host Marriott, the real estate arm spun off in 1993.

name: Billionaires
bio: A marketing executive turned entrepreneur. While sitting in the bar at the Mandarin Hotel in Hong Kong in 1982 he had the idea to market popular Asian energy drinks to European consumers. In 1984 teamed up with Thai businessman Chaleo Yoovidhya, who manufactured high-energy beverages, to sell the concoction to European consumers. Renamed the beverage Red Bull, packaged it in sleek silver-and-blue cans and marketed it to young people with cheeky advertising. Keeps brand in the news these days by sponsoring extreme sports like wind-powered kiteboards and waterfall kayaking. Owns 49% of the now $1.4 billion (sales) company. A very fit-looking 58-year-old bachelor, Matechitz has his own hangar, where he keeps his collection of old planes, including a DC-6 which once belonged to Marshal Tito. He also sponsors the World Stunt Awards, an annual fundraiser to benefit his Taurus Foundation, which helps injured stunt professionals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Telecom bust hit Matthews hard. Barely makes the billionaires list after stake in French telco Alcatel plunged from $1 billion to $100 million. (Alcatel has rebounded some since its October low.) Nonetheless, he presses on with Ontario-based tech firms March Networks and Mitel and keeps tabs on myriad venture cap investments that could blossom in a tech recovery. Meanwhile, he’s building a championship golf resort in Canada. Already owns Celtic Manor, the top resort in homeland Wales, which will play host to golf’s Ryder Cup in 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joined family owned wholesale grocery business 1959 at second shift after Baylor undergrad and Michigan State B-school.  Added 16 distribution facilities across U.S. as president and CEO; appointed chairman by 1992 with 30% average yearly sales growth since 1964.  Sold to tennis buddy Sam Walton for cash and a split-adjusted 22.4 million Wal-Mart stake.  Now owns Houston Astros and chairs privately owned holding company McLane Group, food manufacturer, warehouser and distributor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made software billionaire Shiv Nadar restructured his $907 million (revenues) HCL Group, India’s leading IT group, which fell prey to the global tech spending slowdown. Merged all software business into flagship HCL Technologies in a bid to shore up its stock price, off nealry 30% last year. Diluted his stake in computer education firm NIIT, a declining business,while his firm invested in IT joint ventures with British Telecom, Jones Apparel Group and Deutsche Bank. Spends most of his time in California, drumming up business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns Aruze, Japan's largest manufacturer of Pachislot, a kind of slot machine. Hurt recently by competitors' new and more successful products. Profits are expected to fall by 46% for the year ending in March, 2002. One of its game development subsidiaries declared bankruptcy in October. The company still has a 30% market share but Okada's ray of hope may lie elsewhere. He is partnering with American Steve Wynn to develop a casino resort in Las Vegas slated for a 2004 opening.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime chief executive of Swiss-based luxury products group Richemont, whose brands include Cartier and Dunhill, added title of chairman to his résumé this year. Goal for next year undoubtedly is to fix operating profits, which fell 32% for the year ending March 2002. Also owns stakes in South African-based Remgro, which has tobacco, mining and financial-services interests, and VenFin, a technology-and-telecom concern. Big golfer, splits time between Switzerland and Stellenbosch, a bucolic South African town known for its wine.

name: Billionaires
bio: The “Gilded Lily.” The widow of banker Edmond Safra moved to London last year, immediately vaulting her into the British society pages, thanks to friendships with Camilla Parker Bowles and Prince Charles. She had her own fortune before Edmond’s tragic death in his Monaco penthouse, due in part to inheritances from first two tycoon husbands. Last year, put two New York City apartments on the market for a reported $30 million and $18 million. No buyers as of press time.

name: Billionaires
bio: A people’s billionaire for Mexico, Salinas brings financial services to the impoverished, neglected Mexican masses through his retail conglomerate Grupo Elektra and his new bank, Banco Azteca. At the same time his Mexican television network, second in the market, continues to whittle away at the huge market share of leading broadcaster Televisa. Unfortunately for Salinas, even as his ratings climb, advertising revenues have yet to catch up. His latest venture is Azteca America, the third Spanish-language network in the U.S. It hit some bumps this year, thanks to a raft of lawsuits and countersuits between him and his U.S. distributor over delays in reaching nationwide coverage.

name: Billionaires
bio: With help from son Luis Carlos Jr., continues to run the family’s massive banking conglomerate Aval admidst Colombia’s economic and social upheaval. When not managing his banking, telecommunications and real estate holdings, Sarmiento likes to spend time in the Bahamas at the Cotton Bay Club.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Richard Beatty Mellon; along with sister Cordelia Scaife May (see) inherited big chunk of Mellon banking fortune after mother died in 1965. Controls small daily-paper chain Westminster Media Group, including the archconservative Pittsburgh Tribune-Review. Backs conservative think tanks; investor in right-wing news Web site NewsMax.com. Brother and sister long estranged after Richard accused CordeliaOs late husband of corruption.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joined father at Omaha construction outfit Peter Kiewit Sons' after earning civil engineering degree from Colorado State. Named chief executive in 1979. Invested excess capital in fiber-optic networks, geothermal power plants; branched off as MFS Communications in 1992 with Donald Sturm (see), sold for $15.4 billion in WorldCom stock in 1996. Former WorldCom board member, no longer a shareholder; sold most of WorldCom stock over the past few years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bank examiner got taste for takeovers after buying Dallas drugstore in 1961 for $5,000; sold chain to Eckerd Corp. for $50 million in 1973. Built holding company Valhi through hostile takeovers. SchoolteachersO son denied allegations this year that he was conspiring with ousted founders to take control of Hollywood Casino.

name: Billionaires
bio: Raised in Illinois housing project, worked the racehorse circuit in Omaha before starting Excel Communications, telemarketer of long-distance service. Took it public in 1996, sold to TeleGlobe in 1998 (acquired first privately by CanadaOs BCE in 2000). Returned to horses. With fellow Excel centimillionaire William Casner, owns Our Emblem, sire of this yearOs Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner, War Emblem.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of University of Kentucky to pursue piloting dreams. Flew for PanAm for 10 years; launched pilot-training FlightSafety International 1951. Took public 1968. Sold to Warren Buffett for Berkshire Hathaway stock 1996. Heads Orbis International, nonprofit combating blindness worldwide.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Former billboard magnate now in hospitality business via White Lodging 
Services: manages more than 80 hotels, primarily Marriotts. Says market crash, travel slowdown haven't hurt properties. Graduate of Merchant Marine Academy took over dad's billboard business 1946, sold to Chancellor for $960 million 1998. Self-professed technology dinosaur launched Profile Systems 1997 to monitor billboard lighting via satellite.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grande dame of daytime TV has talk show airing in 104 countries, magazine and production company. The American has no plans to take her company public.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold Sterling Software to Computer Associates two years ago for $4 billion, holds minor CA stake. In June launched proxy battle against CA to oust Chairman Charles Wang, four board members. No wonder: his CA warrants, valued at $55 million a year ago down 75%. But Sam still got paid $10 million to drop complaints and renew his noncompete clause for five years.
